TG-AST090005.name: TG-AST090005
TG-AST090005.project_abstract:
The first billion years of cosmic time witnessed the formation 
of the first galaxies and stars, whose UV radiation gradually 
burned through the surrounding intergalactic medium ("IGM"), 
transforming it from a cold, diffuse gas of neutral atoms to a 
10,000 K - hot gas of ions and electrons. This "epoch of reionization" 
("EOR") filled space with a patchwork quilt of giant ionized zones 
and neutral zones, until the ionized zones eventually grew to 
fill all of space. The EOR is one of the last unexplored 
windows of cosmic time subject to direct observation, and a 
crucial missing link in our astronomical confirmation of the 
current standard theory of cosmology, the Cold Dark Matter 
("CDM") model. Towards that end, we have pioneered the 
large-scale numerical simulation of this phenomenon, to 
predict a host of observable consequences with which to 
test the theory, ranging from the redshifted cosmic 
21cm background from hydrogen atoms in the neutral zones 
during the EOR, to the angular fluctuations of the 
cosmic microwave background introduced when those photons 
scatter off free electrons in the ionized zones, to the 
quenching of light from the earliest galaxies when their 
Lyman alpha emission lines resonantly scatter off the trace of 
neutral atoms left behind inside the ionized zones. EOR 
simulations involve two ingredients: (1) gravitational N-body 
simulation of large-scale structure formation in a volume 
large enough to provide a fair sample of the universe and 
the geometry of its patchy ionization, with a large enough 
particle number to resolve the formation of all the galactic 
halos that are important sources of reionization photons; and 
(2) a separate simulation to transport the ionizing radiation 
released by all those galactic sources, until the ionized 
patches created by these galaxies eventually grow to overlap. 
The N-body simulation provides the underlying gas density 
field of the IGM into which that radiation propagates, 
and identifies all the galactic halos that form over 
time to supply the reionization photons. The radiative transfer 
simulation performs ray-tracing from each source while 
solving the nonequilibrium ionization balance rate equations 
at each point in space, to determine the opacity. We have 
recently developed two, new, massively- parallel methods for 
these two ingredients, more powerful than those we previously 
used to simulate cosmic reionization, and we propose here to 
use them to advance the study of this subject to a new level, 
by utilizing the capabilities of the new Sun Constellation 
cluster at TACC (Ranger). For the N-body simulation, we will 
employ our new CUBEP3M method, a newly parallelized version 
of the Particle-Particle/Particle-Mesh code, to perform an 
unprecedented, extremely high-resolution study (with 165 billion 
particles) of an intermediate-sized volume, to show how the 
IGM gas is clumpy on very small scales, which greatly affects 
its recombination rate and the rate of large-scale reionization, 
and to resolve the smallest galactic halos -- the "minihalos" of 
mass below 100 million solar masses. What makes these high-resolution 
N-body results so special is that they will not only have extremely 
high mass resolution, they will have it in a large enough volume to 
show how this small-scale structure is modulated by longer-wavelength 
density fluctuations, of the kind responsible for the large-scale 
structure of the universe. This will then provide a spatially-varying, 
statistical subgrid model for IGM gas clumping and minihalos to use 
in a large-scale reionization simulation of a much larger volume, 
utilizing our newly parallelized radiative transfer code, C2-RAY 
("Conservative, Causal, Ray-Tracing"), to study the effect of gas 
clumping and minihalos on global reionization, as we transfer the 
radiation from the millions of galaxies within that volume. These 
two simulations, and two smaller-volume C2-Ray simulations that 
will use the new N-body results directly to test the subgrid model, 
will together require 7 million SUs requested here. They will 
reveal the critical impact of spatially-varying gas clumping and 
minihalos on cosmic reionization for the first time. 

[NEW PARAGRAPH]
Among the fundamental underpinings of the CDM universe cosmology which
our studies of cosmic reionization adopt as the "standard model" are
the following: (1) the primordial density fluctuations responsible for
structure formation were Gaussian random noise with a scale-invariant
power spectrum, as predicted by theories of cosmic inflation; and (2)
the total mass-energy density of the universe today is dominated by
dark energy that acts like Einstein's cosmological constant and has
caused cosmic expansion to accelerate. These underpinnings are
consistent with current observations but will be subject to
significantly improved test by upcoming, large-scale galaxy redshift
surveys of the epoch from the end of the EOR down to the present. For
this purpose, it is necessary to simulate the large-scale structure
formation in a very large volume, large enough to compare directly
with the entire volume of these future galaxy surveys. This must be as
large as ~100 cubic Gigaparsecs,to probe the shape of the primordial
density fluctuation power spectrum and constrain non-Gaussianity,
measure the Baryon Acoustic Oscillations ("BAO") and probe the nature
of dark energy. We propose to use the same CubeP3M N-body code we
described above for smaller-volume reionization simulations, also to
perform a series of very large-scale structure ("VLSS") simulations to
model these upcoming galaxy surveys. These latter simulations will
require an additional 2.5 million SUs, bringing the total requested
here to 9.5 million SUs.

TG-CHE140052.name: TG-CHE140052
TG-CHE140052.project_abstract: Photoheterolysis reactions are similar to the canonical organic chemistry unimolecular substitution reaction (Sn1), in that both processes require the initial heterolysis of a carbon  leaving group bond as the first step.  In the highly studied Sn1 reaction, the entire process takes place on the singlet ground state energy surface, and the ability of chemistry to manipulate this reaction stems from our great understanding of the nature of that singlet surface.  There are well developed strategies for either stabilizing or destabilizing the resulting singlet carbocation, which either speeds up or slows down the reaction, respectively.  Unfortunately, there is very little information regarding photoheterolysis reactions as these reactions take place on the excited, singlet but more commonly triplet, energy surfaces.  It is only recently that chemists have started to study these reactions with a goal of identifying the mechanism of photoheterolysis and what happens to the intermediate, a triplet carbocation.  It has been proposed recently that the triplet carbocation behaves differently from the singlet carbocation, therefore requiring a new set of rules to manipulate this reaction.  However, the final product of the photolysis will relax back forming a ground state singlet organic molecule.  We would like to investigate theoretically the triplet reaction energy surface of known photoheterolytic molecules in the hopes developing rules that could be applied to stabilize the triplet carbocation intermediate, thus increasing the rate of the photolysis.   Furthermore we would like to understand how the triplet intermediate, once formed, relaxes back to the ground state singlet, as this process is spin forbidden yet must happen.  We propose that the triplet carbocation intermediate upon reaction with a solvent or suitable nucleophile is induced to relatively small yet higher excited triplet state that allows for the nucleophilic addtion to take place.  It is this structure that would then phosphoresce resulting in the final singlet state product.  Highlevel quantum mechanical calculations should begin to provide an insight into the energy levels of the singlet and triplet ground and excited states.

TG-CHE160009.name: TG-CHE160009
TG-CHE160009.project_abstract: A high-resolution experimental picture of the transition state of a catalytic asymmetric reaction provides vital clues that aid in the design of novel catalyst architectures and more selective catalytic processes. The main objectives of the proposed work are (1) lend quality arguments to highly debated mechanisms of currently used reactions and (2) gain an in-depth understanding of how non-conventional H-bonding (NCHB) interactions can be exploited using isotopically enriched catalysts to influence transition state assemblies and stereoselectivity in enantioselective catalysis. These objectives are addressed using a combined experimental and theoretical mechanistic approach. Experimental 13C and 2H kinetic isotope effects (KIEs) using NMR methodology at natural abundance is employed as a design tool in the elucidation of reaction mechanisms. Theoretical modeling of the relevant transition states, using density functional theory (DFT) and ab-inito calculations, is used to rationalize experimental observations. The mechanistic information gleaned from this approach is utilized as a guide for the rational design of new catalysts and novel strategies in asymmetric catalysis. Using the isotopically edited catalysts to increase enantiomeric excess represents a fundamentally different approach in enantioselective catalysis. This concept has not, to the best of our knowledge, been realized in any systems. Asymmetric organocatalysis presents an ideal opportunity to develop such a general strategy since each of the distinct activation modes in organocatalysis such as enamine, iminium, and Brnsted acid/base catalysis - is associated with sites for possible NCHB. Computational chemistry will be used as the key tool in studying existing examples which will lay the foundation for developing novel processes.

TG-MCA93S001.name: TG-MCA93S001
TG-MCA93S001.project_abstract:
We will use 2 methods, molecular dynamics simulations and diagrammatic theory, to study the properties of proteins and nucleic acids in aqueous saline solution. The molecular dynamics simulations will be used to interpret structural
and thermodynamic experimental data for the biopolymer projects. Using recent classical force eld models these systems will be simulated with molecular dynamics using programs developed in this lab. 
The following ongoing scientic projects of biochemical/biotechnological signicance related to the this renewal
are described: 1)Salt effects in Peptide and Protein Solutions: non-ideal behavior, 2)DNA melting 3)Evaluation of probability densities by integral equations.
These are an ongoing set of funded projects. Considerable progress has been made with the last allocation and we
expect to finish the supplemental allocation before the end of this quarter. Several manuscripts have been and are being
completed; these are listed in a separate section of this document along with progress on code optimization.

Histone11_randomizat.project_abstract:
Randomization of 11 histone modification.

TG-MCB150119.name: TG-MCB150119
TG-MCB150119.project_abstract:
This application is for an allocation of 12,394,852 SUs on the TACC Stampede cluster to conduct mechanistic computational studies of an important lipid trafficking protein unit, STARD4 (steroidogenic acute regulatory protein-related lipid-transfer domain) and its functional interactions with lipid membranes. The planned computations involve extensive atomistic molecular dynamics (MD) simulations of STARD4-membrane systems and are required to achieve specific aims of the NIH grant R37 DK27083, PI Frederick Maxfield, Department of Biochemistry, Weill Cornell Medical College (WCMC). 
The physiological role of the soluble protein domain STARD4 is to transfer sterol molecules between membranes of different cellular organelles. The proposal seeks to determine the mechanistic role that different types of inositol lipids in the membrane have in functional mechanism of STARD4. Studies in the PIs lab have established that in order to accomplish the transfer function, the STARD4 protein is selectively targeted to membrane domains enriched in anionic lipids by a region rich in basic residues. An intriguing observation is the differential regulation of STARD4 activity by two different but closely related lipid components of the membrane, PIP(4,5)2 and PIP(3,5)2 (phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate and 3,5-bisphosphate, respectively). The difference is all the more remarkable as these two physiologically important lipid components carry the same highly negative net charge. Preliminary computations performed by the co-PI, George Khelashvili (Department of Physiology and Biophysics, WCMC), have already identified specific locations on the STARD4 protein that are engaged in strong electrostatic interactions with PIP(4,5)2 lipids, and showed how mutations in STARD4 found in our experiments to inhibit function, can modulate these interactions. To accomplish the Specific Aims of the NIH grant supporting this work we have designed collaboratively a series of computational experiments building on these preliminary mechanistic studies, that require the large-scale MD simulations described in this allocation request.The computational work will be carried out in the Khelashvili lab following the collaborative protocols we have established, integrated with the cognate experiments. The protocols we have designed will i) investigate how the interactions with the various lipid components position the STARD4 domain at the membrane and prepare it for sterol binding/release events; and ii) establish a rigorous structural and dynamic context for the experimentally observed differential regulation of STARD4 activity by different inositol lipid types, and how various mutations affect such regulation. The planned computational studies are essential for achieving an understanding of the molecular mechanisms of intracellular sterol transport.
TG-MCB150119.pi_institution: Weill Cornell Medical College of Cornell University

TG-CHE160001.name: TG-CHE160001
TG-CHE160001.project_abstract:
In this current investigation, my group has developed a cyclopentadiene-based chiral Brnsted acid. This novel chiral catalyst has demonstrated efficiency in asymmetric Mukaiyama-Mannich reactions, nucleophilic additions to oxocarbenium surrogates and transfer-hydrogenations. The catalyst differs from the established BINOL Brnsted acid architecture in the ease of synthesis of the catalyst and precludes the use of pyrophoric organolithium reagents for catalyst modification.   Our new catalytic platform is capable of performing the benchmark Mukaiyama-Mannich reaction in the green solvent ethyl acetate in less than five minutes, a massive improvement on the current paradigm of running the reaction in aromatic solvents for periods of up to two days. The products of this reaction are rendered in enantiomeric excesses of ~99%, while diastereoselectivity is still in an optimization phase.

The aim of this physical organic project is to identify and characterize the rate-determining step (RDS) and stereoselectivity-determining step of the catalytic cycles of both the Mukaiyama-Mannich reaction and the nucleophilic addition to oxocarbeniums. While prior investigations into BINOL-phosphoric acid (BNPH) catalyzed variants of the Mukaiyama-Mannich reaction have shown that one or two hydrogen-bonding acceptors sites are vital design elements for selectivity, this cyclopentadiene-based platform has approximately a dozen sites. Preliminary gas-phase density functional theory calculations of transition-state (TS) structures have shown a complex network of intramolecular and intermolecular hydrogen bonds. Perhaps the most fascinating of these interactions is a pair of C-H interactions between the activated electrophile and the negatively charged pi-system of the catalyst.  The theoretical work supports work with our collaborator at Binghamton University, the Vetticatt group. The Vetticatt group is currently measuring experimental kinetic isotope effects (KIEs), the purpose of which is to determine the atoms involved in the RDS. The theoretical models will serve to rationalize experimental KIEs and selectivities.

BACKGROUND AND SIGNIFICANCE

The asymmetric organocatalysis is a fledging field with a scarcity of mechanistic data. The goal of developing organocatalytic variants of asymmetric reactions is to reduce reliance on rare or toxic transition metal catalysts. Bypassing the use of these metals allows the scientific community to stem groundwater contamination, curb the need for air-free techniques, and discovery reactions amenable to biological conditions.  In the design of effective catalysts, fundamental insights into reactivity must be collected. Substoichiometric quantities of Brnsted acid are known to catalyze a diverse array of fundamental reactions in organic synthesis. Chiral BNPHs and chiral thioureas are privileged motifs in asymmetric Brnsted catalysis, as they are known to affect a wide array of indispensable asymmetric transformations such as nitro-Michael, Mannich, Nazarov, Friedel-Crafts and Diels-Alder reactions. 

While current efforts are focused on the benchmark Mukaiyama-Mannich reaction, the addition to oxocarbeniums is to become another area of investigation. The addition to oxocarbeniums is a less explored reaction with a dearth of mechanistic data. The models derived from this study will help predict and tune reaction selectivity as well as test new reactions in silico. In addition to the mechanistic contribution to fundamental science, the merit of this work is to further improve on a cutting-edge organocatalytic platform that will find utility in sustainable chemistry, medicinal chemistry and organic synthesis. 

COMPUTATIONAL METHODOLOGY

Accurate theoretical modeling of these systems is an arduous feat as the TS structures for the Mukaiyama-Mannich reaction feature 221 atoms. The methodology used for preliminary results has been to use force field and molecular mechanics methods in an exhaustive conformational analysis. Upon finding major conformers of the catalyst, TS structures are calculated with the ONIOM (B3LYP 6-31G*/ AM1) method available through Gaussian09 Rev E.01. One of the calculated transition-state models for each enantiomer is then recalculated at full B3LYP 6-31G*. Due to the sheer size of the system, each calculation uses extensive computational resources (~800 service-units). This project requires the maximum allowed allocation of service-units in order to be comprehensive. The SUs will enable further analysis of TS structures at high levels of theory and afford a thorough analysis of structures that contribute to reactivity.

TG-CTS090004.name: TG-CTS090004
TG-CTS090004.project_abstract: The goal of this research is twofold: (i) to understand the role of turbulence in the generation of sound in modern aircraft turbo-machinery, and (ii) to develop computational methods for controlling the sound.   It is well known that certain geometrical modifications to aircraft engines can reduce their radiated noise.  However, there is no manner to predict which modifications will actually reduce the noise, resulting in lengthy---and costly---experimental programs to parametrically study candidate design modifications.  This deficiency is due to the conceptual, experimental, and computational challenges associated with turbulence-generated sound and, hence, in developing effective control methods.  By solving the compressible Navier-Stokes equations directly, this research provides foundational descriptions of the sound-generating fluid motions and subsequent development of optimized control methodologies.  The PI's code is based on advanced finite difference techniques and scales at 90\% of perfect up to 1024 processors on TACC's Ranger.  This work follows up the previous DACs TG-CTS080019 (DJB) and TG-CTS080030N (JBF).  Financial support for this work is provided by three separate grants from NASA and the AeroAcoustics Research Consortium on which the current investigators are PI's or co-PI.  It builds upon large-scale aeroacoustic simulation work from past NASA and AFOSR grants.  Total requested allocation is 14,000K SUs.

TG-CTS100027.name: TG-CTS100027
TG-CTS100027.project_abstract: Density functional theory will be used to study charge distributions, atomic charges, bond indices, and other chemical descriptors in complex materials, especially as they relate to catalytic reactions. The study focuses on understanding how these properties effect molecular adsorption and catalytic reactions occurring on (a) solid surfaces, (b) homogeneous transition metal complexes, and (c) porous materials. For each material, a variety of population analysis methods will be used to study the role of charge transfer during the adsorption or reaction process. This understanding may be used to design materials with improved performance.

TG-MCB090174.name: TG-MCB090174
TG-MCB090174.field_of_science: Biochemistry and Molecular Structure and Function

TG-ASC140026.name: TG-ASC140026
TG-ASC140026.project_abstract: Computational Anatomy is a discipline focused on the quantitative analysis of the variability in biological shape. Large Deformation Diffeomorphic Metric Mapping (LDDMM) is the key algorithm, which assigns computable descriptors of anatomical shapes and a metric distance between them. This is achieved by describing populations of anatomy as a group of diffeomorphic transformations applied to a template, and using a metric on the space of diffeomorphisms. LDDMM is being used extensively in the neuroimaging (\url{www.mristudio.org}) and cardiovascular imaging (\url{www.cvrgrid.org}) communities. Modern high resolution scanners are producing images which require the computational power of multiple processing units. One of our goals is to analyze the high-resolution images on large memory (1TB memory) machines with the existing openMP implementation of LDDMM. The initial startup year was extremely successful in meeting our goals and a science gateway has been created. The Computational Anatomy Science Gateway (\url{https://www.xsede.org/gateways-listing}) is established to support neuroimaging community. In this year, we plan to continue with development and expansion of the science gateway role to support these two communities. The neuroimaging community (\url{www.mristudio.org}) that this gateway will support has 6000 users, who are beginning to transfer to our science gateway model, while we continue to expand our user base. Our local cluster has processed over 47K brains since 2009 which required 450K CPU-hrs on 8 core nodes with 32GB of memory. Over the past year we have begun to offload the majority of jobs from our local cluster to XSEDE resources. The gateway is enabling the processing of large populations in parallel on multiple cores. With these new data sets, innovations in software optimization, and algorithms that benefit from statistical knowledge of populations are being explored. Significant development with GPGPUs has occured, and we hope to further exploit the Xeon Phi co-processors in the same manner. In addition to the neuroimaging community, the cardiovascular community (\url{www.cvrgrid.org}) will also utilize the gateway for shape analysis (\url{http://cvrgrid.org/features/cardiac-c}) in the future if resources allow.

TG-MCA94P017.name: TG-MCA94P017
TG-MCA94P017.project_abstract: An allocation is requested for large scale computer simulations of multiple and single proton transport (PT) in biomolecular systems, coarse-graining, and large multi-scale simulations of biological assemblies. In the case of PT, the interaction of the proton with the biomolecular environment is represented by the multi-state empirical valence bond (MS-EVB) method, and the potential of mean force (PMF) along the pathway of PT is calculated by averaging over highly parallel swarms of trajectories. A novel methodology to simulate multiple protons, based on the MS-EVB, has just been developed by our group and scales nearly linearly with proton number. Large atomistic simulations of biological assemblies will be performed in order to systematically parameterize coarse-grained mesoscopic models that will be employed to examine long time- and length-scale phenomena. Multi-scale coupled simulations of embedded proteins in lipid bilayers, as well as spectrin filaments will be employed to directly examine atomistic-level couplings with mesoscopic phenomena. These studies are extremely challenging and well suited to parallel supercomputing environments.

TG-MCB060061N.name: TG-MCB060061N
TG-MCB060061N.project_abstract:
Supercomputer resources are requested to support five projects supported by federally funded grants. The projects range from the exploration of folding landscapes, to the dynamics of proteins in bilayers. The proposed projects will also support research by
undergraduates participating in our fund NSF-REU program. Last years resource utilization resulted in six manuscripts. This is a request for supplemental SUs to assist in finishing a couple of manuscripts.

TG-DMR150040.name: TG-DMR150040
TG-DMR150040.project_abstract:
The combination of several newly discovered 2D materials into van der Waals heterostructures utilizes synergies in their structural and electronic properties to unlock new applications in optoelectronics, sensors, and composite materials. Liquid-phase self-assembly provides a facile and scalable route for the production of these heterogenous stacks of layered 2D materials. However, despite the wide spread usage of liquid phase exfoliation and stabilization for a variety of layered nanomaterials, there is still a lack of understanding of the role of the molecular structure and ordering in the exfoliation medium. 

Through all-atomistic molecular dynamics simulations, we intend to elucidate the significance of several molecular-level descriptors, including bulkiness, geometry, enhanced intermolecular cohesion, and ordering, of commonly used nanomaterial solvents in the aggregation of nanomaterial flakes. From these computational investigations, we hope to determine design rules to identify solvents which are most conducive to the self-assembly of a given ordered stack of 2D nanomaterials.

Epistasis-influncing.name: Epistasis-influncing
Epistasis-influncing.project_abstract: Gene-Gene interactions are essential components of the genetic architecture of the gene expressions. But, gene-gene interaction analysis of gene expressions remains fundamentally unexplored due to great computational challenges and data availability. On the other hand, considering the fact that many biological synthetic process require the balanced expression of multiple genes, analyzing the regulation mechanism of highly correlated gene expressions is crucial. However, simultaneously analyzing gene-gene interactions for highly correlated gene expressions poses enormous challenges for methodologies and computations: 1) lack of methods for gene-gene interaction analysis of multiple gene expressions, 2) severe multiple testing, 3) heavy computation burden.  To meet these challenges, we use multivariate functional regression method for testing gene-gene interaction and estimating its effect in regulating gene expressions.
Epistasis-influncing.pi_institution: University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston

TG-MCB050008N.name: TG-MCB050008N
TG-MCB050008N.project_abstract: The overall goal of this research is to understand the electron transfer properties of electron transfer proteins at a molecular level, using computer simulations and other theoretical methods.  The focus is on the Fe-S proteins, especially the [1Fe] rubredoxins, the [2Fe-2S] Rieske-type proteins, and the [4Fe-4S]-type ferredoxins.  These ubiquitous proteins are involved in fundamental processes such as respiration and photosynthesis.  However, despite the rapidly growing number of crystal structures, the structural origins of the electron transfer properties of these proteins remain unclear.  The focus here is on understanding the environmental contribution to the reduction potentials and electron transfer rates of these proteins. Our approach uses computational methods including molecular dynamics simulations of the protein along with electronic structure calculations of redox site analogs.  A crucial feature in simulating these proteins is the accurate treatment of solvent effects.   The aims specific to the iron-sulfur proteins concern understanding the effects of mutations on reduction potentials and activation energies and the protein dynamics during electron transfer.  In addition, aims specific to solvent effects concern testing new models of liquid water for computer simulations for solvation properties of simple solutes as well as an iron-sulfur protein.

TG-MCB060011N.name: TG-MCB060011N
TG-MCB060011N.project_abstract:
In the realm of fundamental and applied sciences, the interface between nanotechnology and biotechnology is rapidly evolving. At this interface, quantitative description of underlying fundamental processes is inherently a multiscale problem. In this proposal, we strive to achieve a multiscale description of equilibrium and dynamic processes associated 
biomolecular interactions by pursuing the following aims. (1) Develop and apply free energy methods in conjunction with a quantum mechanics molecular mechanics (QMMM) Hamiltonian to describe enzyme catalytic mechanisms. (2) Apply free energy methods in conjunction with molecular dynamics to descrive enzyme conformational activation and substrate recognition. (3) Develop and apply multiscale spatially resolved hybrid deterministic/ stochastic algorithms for studying signal transduction. The proposed studies are likely to have a significant impact in nanobiotechnology and systems biology in terms of enabling fundamental scientific discoveries, as well as driving rational design.

Computational-Cosmol.name: Computational-Cosmol
Computational-Cosmol.project_abstract: For the last decade, several cosmological observations have been indicating that the expansion of the universe is accelerating.  The cosmic acceleration constitutes one of the most important and challenging current problems in cosmology and all physics.  Several possible causes or explanations have been proposed.  These include a cosmological constant, or some other form of repulsive dark energy, i.e. negative pressure and negative equation of state, a modification to general relativity at cosmological scales of distances, or an apparent effect of inhomogeneities in the universe.  Dr. Jacob Moldenhauer, Assistant Professor of Physics, currently tests these explanations of cosmic acceleration for consistency with many of the latest cosmological observations of both the expansion history and growth of structure formation in the universe.  These tests are performed using a modified version of the publicly available Monte Carlo Markov Chain code for cosmology, cosmoMC, (A. Lewis and S. Bridle, 2002).  This code is used along with certain packages, or modules like ISiTGR, (J. Dossett, M. Ishak and J. Moldenhauer, 2011) designed to test for consistency with general relativity using elegant parameterizations for modeling the dark energy at different times in the universe’s evolution.

TG-DMR090006.name: TG-DMR090006
TG-DMR090006.project_abstract:
As part of an academic/industrial collaborative effort between the University of Illinois and General Motors R\&D through NSF's GOALI program, we are beginning a computational study of dislocation/solute interactions in HCP metals, specifically for the critical problem of building accurate deformation models for magnesium alloys.  We model pure Mg dislocation geometries and properties, as well as the effects of Al solutes via two main tasks: 1. determining the dislocation core for basal and non-basal dislocations in pure Mg at zero and finite stress using density-functional theory with flexible boundary conditions; 2. substituting Al at sites around the Mg dislocation cores to determine solute/dislocation interactions with density-functional theory.  Key to this work are high-performance computing resources to perform the study.

The objective of this study is to apply electronic-structure methods for the study of dislocations for Mg and Mg alloys and incorporate this data into finite-element constitutive models.  Connecting fundamental electronic structure studies of deformation at the atomistic scale to finite element modeling for new alloy design and direct incorporation in industrial usage is a potentially transformative concept in materials science and engineering.  It offers the promise to move beyond traditional trial-and-error approaches, and the combined talents of the academic-industrial collaboration is uniquely positioned to approach this problem.  Computational resources from TeraGrid combined with dedicated local resources are necessary to expand the work to enough dislocation types, stresses, and solute sites to provide meaningful data.

Peridynamics-and-fin.name: Peridynamics-and-fin
Peridynamics-and-fin.project_abstract: This project is to support our 3-D simulations using both Peridynamics and finite volume codes.
Peridynamics-and-fin.pi_institution: Department of Petroleum and Geosystems Engineering

TG-MCB140274.name: TG-MCB140274
TG-MCB140274.project_abstract: Influenza is one of the most wide spread diseases and severely affects the health of millions of human beings annually. Our lab computationally studies Influenza hemagglutinin (HA2), the homotrimeric viral surface protein that facilitates host-viral membrane fusion both by introducing its fusion peptides into the host membrane and through a large conformational rearrangement. Our coarse-grained studies have brought up interesting questions that are important in order to understand the molecular mechanism of membrane fusion mediated by HA2. Here, to address these questions, we request a total of 4.7 million SUs on Stampede supercomputer, to perform explicit-solvent molecular dynamics simulations with a newly developed single-copy enhanced sampling method and the CHARMM36 force field. Project 1 needs 2.5 million SUs to map out the free energy landscape of the B-loop domain of HA2, which undergoes a loop-to-coiled-coil transition that presents the fusion peptides to the host membrane. There is much controversy in the field as to whether the B-loop is enthalpically-downhill driven (spring-loaded), or whether there is a significant entropic barrier to its transition. Our simulations will conclusively discern the mechanism of this transition. Project 2 needs 2.2 million SUs to address the dynamics and structure of fusion peptides once they have been introduced into the host membrane. Through simulations, we will find out whether the fusion peptides aggregrate, form a specific functional oligomer, or simply provide an anchor for HA2. Prospective results from these two projects will shed light on the generic membrane fusion mechanism shared by influenza viruses and other viruses such as HIV and Ebola. Additionally, an understanding of the molecular mechanism for fusion will highlight the vulnerable regions of HA2 on which to concentrate drug research.

TG-MCA94P030.name: TG-MCA94P030
TG-MCA94P030.project_abstract: Our group is engaged in research in the fields of theoretical condensed matter physics and materials science. Using computers as a primary tool a wide range of properties and materials are studied with the twin goals of understanding microscopic mechanisms and their relationship to experimental observations, and using this understanding to make predictions about real materials and devices. The materials and systems studied all either have important technological applications, address physical questions of fundamental importance, or provide a testing ground for new theoretical and computational techniques.

TG-ATM100048.name: TG-ATM100048
TG-ATM100048.project_abstract: The proposed work aims to improve our understanding of severe convective storms through continued use of numerical models using MPI.  Of particular interest is how the storm's environment influences tornado intensity and longevity.  We are accomplishing this using a suite of tornadic and non-tornadic environmental soundings provided by the Storm Prediction Center and understanding why/how these factors impact tornado formation.  We are also attempting to simulate the most infamous tornadic supercell in history: the 18 March 1925 Tri-State supercell.  Our research group, in collaboration with Dr. Bob Wilhelmson's group at UIUC/NCSA, continues to add and test more sophisticated microphysics schemes and other model improvements.  Improving microphysics is important since a storms' own microphysical processes affect cold pools which are known to impact tornado potential and the reliability of short-term tornado forecasts.

TG-MCB110101.name: TG-MCB110101
TG-MCB110101.field_of_science: Biochemistry and Molecular Structure and Function
TG-MCB110101.project_abstract:
This is the PI's rst research request for TeraGrid allocation.

    The objective of PI's research is to develop new algorithms and computer codes that allow one to make the best use of NMR data in determining solution structures of biomolecules, to assess in a systematic fashion the accuracy and precision of the resulting structures, and to explore the extent to which dynamical information can be extracted from NMR data.      

A second direction of the PI's research is to develop molecular simulation tools and protocols
to characterize the conformations and energetics of native and non-native states of peptides and proteins, and to explore the details of pH and salt-induced conformational transitions.

    The PI is the leading developer of the popular AMBER suite of biomolecular simulation programs since 1995.

    The PI's research is supported by the following NIH grants: R01 GM045811, R01 GM057513, P41 RR012255, R01 GM039914 and U01 AI077949.

    The PI has published over 250 research papers, and was recently ranked as number 30 in a list of the most highly-cited chemists for the period 2000-2010 (http://www.sciencewatch.com/dr/sci/misc/Top100Chemists2000-10/).

    The purpose of this request is to fulll the need of computational resources needed by PI's research group.

DNA-or-miRNAs-Hybrid.name: DNA-or-miRNAs-Hybrid
DNA-or-miRNAs-Hybrid.project_abstract: The cardiovascular disease (CVD) is highly correlated with the expression of individual miRNAs and miRNA signatures. We propose to develop unique on-chip sample concentrating and detection procedure/device for CVD, using the combination of multi-scale simulations and experiments. We will perform large-scale parallel atomistic and coarse-grained simulations combined with continuous models to investigate miRNA hybridization during the process of evaporation and macromolecule concentrating, which involves complicated interfacial phenomena. We will also utilize simulations to rationalize the molecular design of molecular probes and the substrate surface of gene chip. Investigation into macromolecular behavior at the solution-surface interface from atomistic/molecular scale is highly computationally demanding. The requested computational resource on TACC supercomputer clusters (0.5 million SUs and 0.5 TB) will be a great help for our proposed research project. Our research team has expertise in HPC, material design/simulation, and theory and experiments of interfacial force/phenomena and bioengineering.

PCSE-2016.name: PCSE-2016
PCSE-2016.project_abstract: Class activities for the PCSE 2016 class. About 50 students expected who are going to learn parallel computing.

Pd-Nazarov.name: Pd-Nazarov
Pd-Nazarov.project_abstract: The Nazarov cyclization reaction is a powerful reaction for the assembly of five membered rings that are a part of many natural products. One such product is terpestacin, which is used in cancer therapy. This drug is difficult to synthesize using current methods and harvesting from plants does not meet the maximum efficiency that is needed. The elucidation of the reaction mechanism of Nazarov cyclization could be used in the more atom efficient synthesis of terpestacin. I will be working on the fine details of the mechanism, several other possible reaction pathways and use these mechanistic information to choose the ligands that would make the Nazarov cyclization a more powerful synthetic method.

Studies-in-vibronic.name: Studies-in-vibronic
Studies-in-vibronic.project_abstract: We plan to do high-level calculations on a number of problems dealing with problems in the following two areas: 1) the calculation of vibronic levels in systems that are poorly described by the Born-Oppenheimer approximation, particularly those with a significant number of degrees of freedom and/or electronic states; 2) advancement of the HEAT protocol for computational thermochemistry to molecules associated with combustion science, both combustion of traditional fossil fuels and also those molecules that are important to what is known as hydrogen combustion.   We have, or are developing, state-of-the art parallel codes for all types of these calculations.

Portugal-2015.name: Portugal-2015
Portugal-2015.project_abstract: Project for Portuguese research interns, Summer 2015

TG-PHY120016.name: TG-PHY120016
TG-PHY120016.project_abstract:
This renewal proposal seeks the continuation of our EXEDE Resources Allocation in support of our numerical relativityeffort on simulations of compact objects and their impact on astrophysics and gravitational astronomy.  Numerical relativity has truly become a tool of discovery. For gravitational wave astrophysics, it has enabled a serious conversation between researchers modeling sources of gravitational radiation and scientists focussed on the intricacies of analyzing the
data collected by interferometric detectors.  The black hole binaries continues to be one of the most transformative challenges at the interface of gravitational wave physics, astrophysics, mathematical relativity and computational
science. The challenge resides in the complexities associated with solving Einstein's equations; in the many scales involved, from those comparable to the binary orbits or gravitational wavelengths to those in the vicinity of the black holes; in the resolutions needed to accurately extract gravitational waveforms; and in the inclusion of physics to model matter sources. 
The allocation requested will support  work on  binary  black holes systems organized in the following closely related project areas: 1) Binary black holes in vacuum to expand parameter space explored to include arbitrary black hole spin orientations and to enhance a bank of  hybrid gravitational waveforms.
2) Binary black holes in astrophysical environments to investigate whether electromagnetic observations are able to detect and characterize the presence of these binary systems. 
3)Binary black holes in alternative theories of gravity to study the late inspiral and merger of a binary coalescences and distinguish between scalar-tensor gravity and general relativity.

TG-AST120022.name: TG-AST120022
TG-AST120022.project_abstract: We request 15 million service units on Stampede to perform and analyze a suite of high resolution simulations of the formation of Milky Way-like galaxies. The primary scientific goal of our joint proposal is to simulate a new, unprecedentedly large set of highly resolved Milky Way sized halos that will open a new window for carrying out computational near-field cosmology.  Of order 70 (20 already complete) such halos will enable a statistically robust investigation of cosmic variance and the nuances of the hierarchical assembly of galaxies, making this simulation suite useful for a large variety of scientific projects in the years to come.

A-ch5111.name: A-ch5111
A-ch5111.project_abstract:
This project aims at developing: (1) a deeper understanding of the fundamental behavior and properties of defect and dopant complexes in strained Si layers and their interfaces with a-SiO2 (with also some effort on high-k dielectrics); and (2) first principles-based kinetic models capable of predicting the evolution of dopant and defect profiles, which is needed for rational experimental designs to realize ultrashallow junctions for the 45-nm node or beyond. 
Continued scaling of CMOS devices down to the 45-nm design node or beyond will require the formation of ever shallower and more abrupt junctions with higher doping levels.  This also requires moving away from bulk CMOS in Si with SiO2 gate dielectrics.  It will probably involve the use of a buried strained Si layer for channel mobility enhancement and high-k dielectrics for gate leakage current reduction.  However, little is known about the fundamental behavior and properties of defects and dopants in strained Si layers and their interfaces with a-SiO2, (let alone high-k dielectrics). 
We perform first principles calculations to determine: structure, stability, and bonding of defect and dopant clusters in amorphous/strained Si layers; formation and diffusion of mobile defect and defect-dopant complexes in strained Si layers and in the vicinity of a-c Si interfaces; and defect annihilation and dopant precipitation at strained-Si/a-SiO2 interfaces. 
We perform first principles based classical molecular dynamics (or ab inito tight binding molecular dynamics, if necessary) simulations to examine complex dynamics occurring in amorphous Si.  Emphasis is placed on understanding: recrystallization of amorphous pockets in the presence of strain and defects; and dynamic behavior of defects in the vicinity of amorphous pockets.  The fundamental findings contribute to developing improved kinetic models for defect profiles during the early stages of post-implantation annealing.

TG-DMR160027.name: TG-DMR160027
TG-DMR160027.project_abstract: I humbly request an HPC allocation to support my projects on the the integration of the typical medium for realistic materials study. The typical medium dynamical cluster approximation (TMDCA) formalism is a mean-field approach designed to properly characterize electron localization and has been recently applied to model systems. This effort includes incorporating the TMDCA with standard density functional theory (TMDCA@DFT), enabling many-body study of electron localization in realistic materials. These resources will be used to study the role of disorder and/or correlations in low-dimensional systems, where due to reduced dimensionality, correlations become important. The TMDCA systematically incorporates non-local corrections to local approximations like the Dynamical Mean Field by mapping a lattice problem onto a self-consistently embedded cluster. This powerful technique will allow for a systematically study of emerging phenomena in parameter regimes that were heretofore inaccessible. I have parallelized (with scale efficiency of up to thousands of processors) and carefully optimized my code as such, per processor performance is very close to optimal. Papers emancipating from the use of this resources will be properly acknowledged.

TG-DMR160024.name: TG-DMR160024
TG-DMR160024.project_abstract: Tantalum arsenide (TaAs) is another kind of semimetal with a 3D structure different from 2D graphene. But what really makes TaAs special and exciting to physicists is its unique symmetry. The inversion symmetry is broken in TaAs leading to the existence of Weyl fermions, a fundamental quasi-particle arises with non-trivial topology. Weyl fermion was firstly indicated by Herann Weyls derivation of Dirac equation for massless fermions and recently it was found in low-energy condensed matter system like TaAs.  Because of the existence of Weyl fermions, TaAs as a Weyl semimetal shows several special properties like surface Fermi arcs, chiral anomaly. Meanwhile, these properties are exposed and confirmed by photoemission spectroscopy and negative magnetoresistance experimentally. Though great efforts have been made to study chiral transport, electron transport in TaAs, seldom do people look into the influence of deformation of lattice on electron behaviors. Previous studies have demonstrated that strain can play a vital role in topological phase transition by changing electron band crossings. Therefore, in this project, we not only want to unveil the mechanism how electron states are tuned by strain applied in TaAs system but try to study the underlying electron-phonon interactions responsible for modulated electron behaviors.

TG-MCB130013.name: TG-MCB130013
TG-MCB130013.project_abstract: Amphiphilic biological polymers (bio-polymers), such as peptides and oligonucleotides, have been shown to singly disperse single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs) in aqueous media. Certain species of SWCNTs, termed chiralities, are semi-conducting and fluoresce in the near-infrared spectrum. Recent studies have shown that sensors can be made from the bio-polymer-SWCNT hybrid constructs to detect specific chemical analytes. These work on the basic principle that a SWCNT's band-gap fluorescence intensity and wavelength are significantly affected by changes to their local environment. In this simulation study, we propose to investigate the structure and characterize their interactions with target analytes. The urokinase plasminogen activator (uPA), a circulating human biomarker that correlates directly with the onset of aggressive metastatic cancer, will be detected by conjugating its antibody (anti-uPA) to a DNA-wrapped SWCNT. In previous molecular dynamics (MD) studies, using XSEDE resources, we have performed detailed studies on the various complex structures that short DNA oligomers conform to when on the surface of SWCNTs.1-4 Using molecular dynamics (MD), we will probe the timescale of specific binding, i.e. uPA to anti-uPA, as well as detect changes in the immediate vicinity of the SWCNT. Replica exchange MD (REMD) will also be used as a tool to extract equilibrium structural information of the functionalized hybrids. In addition to antibody-conjugated DNA-SWCNT sensors, DNA aptamers will also be conjugated to similar hybrids for the detection of small molecule cancer metabolites. Data obtained from the simulations will be used to modify existing nanoparticle sensor hybrids to create more sensitive, robust, and efficient sensors.

TG-PHY130007.name: TG-PHY130007
TG-PHY130007.project_abstract: Laser-based gas acceleration and heating of neutral flows have direct applications to research in gas-surface interactions, high-temperature gas research (e.g. chemistry, gas kinetics, and radiation modeling), hypersonics, and orbital environment simulation.  The University of Colorado Colorado Springs, in collaboration with the Air Force Research Laboratory, is currently working on neutral gas heating via non-resonant pulsed optical lattices formed by counter-propagating laser pulses.  This experimentation is greatly enhanced by complimentary numerical simulation.  Using the Direct Simulation Monte-Carlo method for statistical gas dynamic simulation, the simulations proposed will elucidate the kinetic phenomenon at the core of the interaction between a neutral atmospheric gas and high intensity pulsed optical lattices (lasers).  Current experimental capabilities in diagnosing the underlying mechanisms are limited by the fast time-scales and small length-scales of the interaction.  Numerical simulations are not similarly limited and can give data (e.g. velocity and internal energy distributions) inaccessible to experiment.  In pairing the proposed simulations with existing experimental data, this proposal seeks to gain an inside look at the micro-scale molecular interaction (both molecule-molecule and molecule-laser) which drive the experimentally observed phenomena.  The code used for these simulations is SMILE, a thoroughly tested gas dynamic simulation package written in MPI Fortran 77 and specially modified to simulated the laser-gas interaction of interest.  This simulation tool has been used extensively for similar simulations on DoD HPC facilities, demonstrating the PIs expertise in performing the proposed work.  Two test cases were run on TACC Lonestar and TACC Ranger.  A total simulation time of 175,000 SU on the TACC Lonestar system (or 370,000 SU on Ranger) is being requested to perform the proposed simulations.  The product of these simulations, in addition to insight on the gas dynamic phenomena, will be contributing data to at least two archival journal articles and a doctoral dissertation.

STARIntel-exascale.name: STARIntel-exascale
STARIntel-exascale.field_of_science: COMPUTER AND INFORMATION SCIENCE AND ENGINEERING (CISE)
STARIntel-exascale.project_abstract: Intel requested hours on Stampede for Exascale Labs testing during 2013.

A-ti711.name: A-ti711
A-ti711.project_abstract: New theoretical and computational innovations have recently appeared that present opportunities for addressing previously intractable problems more comprehensively and efficiently than was possible heretofore.  A prime example is the problem of propagation and interaction of a very large number of cracks in complex three-dimensional bodies. The theoretical developments have occurred in the area of phase-field modeling, and the computational developments in isogeometric modeling and analysis.  We believe the time is right to initiate computational mechanics research toward developing them for problems of engineering interest.
A-ti711.pi_institution: Department of Aerospace Engineering and Engineering Mechanics

TG-DMR080070.name: TG-DMR080070
TG-DMR080070.project_abstract:
There are four projects in this proposal. The first project uses molecular dynamics simulations of particles to study mechanical 
properties of nanostructures. In particular, we want to understand the shape and size dependence of the effective spring constants for inverted frustums and compare them to recent theoretical results. This is important to nanostructure synthesis and applications. 

The second project also uses molecular dynamics simulations to study the influence of particle mass modulation on the diffusion of a vibration pulse in isotope nanostructures. An understanding of this will have impact on optimizing the figure of merit (ZT) for thermoelectric materials. 

The third project studies the dynamics of single-file diffusion of softcore fluids in restricted geometry. This is a fundamental phenomena of fluid transport in nanostructures. We will employ particle simulation methods of Monte Carlo, molecular dynamics, and Brownian dynamics to understand single-file diffusion for fluids interacting with soft potentials and compare them with those of hardsphere fluids. The emphasis is to explore hopping times in quasi-one dimensional soft-core fluids. 

Our codes for these projects have been tested and optimized for parallel computers using a maximum of 512 cores with MPI. They are parts of an ongoing productive research program and ten papers have been published under previous small computing grant supports. 

The fourth project is to port some of our codes to GPU with CUDA. GPU and CUDA are new to us. This will let us investigate the applications of GPU. 

A total of 200,000 SU for TeraGrid  Wide Roaming  with access to Lonestar and Lincoln-Tesla is requested for the four projects in 
this proposal.

TG-OCE130016.name: TG-OCE130016
TG-OCE130016.project_abstract: This allocation request is for performing simulations of fine-scale mixing brought about by submesoscale processes (horizontal scale of 100 m - 10 km) which provide pathways to three-dimensional, small-scale turbulence and mixing from eddy kinetic energy and potential energy stored around density fronts. The novelty is the use of turbulence-resolving, high-resolution simulations that enable accurate characterization of small-sale processes including dissipation and mixing that are not resolved by the application of global climate models to submesoscale ocean processes. The new results on the mixing of the upper-ocean stratification by stratified, rotating turbulence will contribute to progress in our existing NSF-funded grants. A startup allocation (Submesoscale Mixing in the Ocean, TG-OCE110017) was awarded last year and results from the large-scale simulations performed using this allocation were included in a paper that was submitted to the Journal of Fluid Mechanics \cite{AroboneS:2013} The new simulations proposed here, by inclusion of a horizontal buoyancy gradient and associated vertical shear, are a natural progression of those conducted with the startup allocation. Barotropic shear flow, a feature that is prevalent in boundary currents and estuarine flows, has remained unexplored in previous investigations of submesoscale frontal dynamics and its inclusion will fill the existing knowledge gap.

TG-DMR140096.name: TG-DMR140096
TG-DMR140096.project_abstract: Organic photovoltaics (OPVs) comprise a promising class of solar cells with a number of unique and desirable qualities. These materials promise the ability to produce a flexible, inexpensive, and thin solar cell as a structurally more versatile and economically more attractive alternative to silicon-based solar cells.  The efficiency of the relatively new OPV materials has not yet reached that of conventional silicon based solar cells and needs to be increased before wide scale commercial application can be realized. OPVs are efficient absorbers of light, but depend upon exciton diffusion, dissociation, and eventually electron-hole separation to generate photocurrent. Competing against these processes is the complementary set of exciton trapping, recombination, and radiative or non-radiative decay. Maximizing the former set and minimizing or negating the latter are available routes to improve efficiency and allow for OPVs to become a viable renewable energy source. Perhaps the most critical complicating factor in understanding OPVs is that the performance is highly sensitive to molecular order, and large variance in molecular order can be seen even within the same polymer, depending on processing protocol.  The research for which this proposal requests support is focused on understanding these performance factors on a fundamental and molecular level in order to aid in the understanding and design of OPV device performance.

HV-INV-MOD.name: HV-INV-MOD
HV-INV-MOD.project_abstract: We propose to develop a framework to calculate the elastic properties of heart valve leaflets from in-vivo imaging like ultrasound. The constitutive law of soft tissues is very complex with around 10 material parameters. And since these parameters are heterogeneous, solving for those material parameters at every point of the valve tissue using inverse model becomes very computationally expensive. We would like to use HPCs to solve this problem. The predicted properties will be correlated to their pathological state. This data will be used in future in clinical settings for determining patient-specific risk of developing a disorder.

STAR-Technip.name: STAR-Technip
STAR-Technip.project_abstract: Numerical wave tank simulations to validate of Euler-Overlay Method

TG-MCB150054.name: TG-MCB150054
TG-MCB150054.field_of_science: Biochemistry and Molecular Structure and Function
TG-MCB150054.project_abstract: We request XSEDE allocations to study the Ras family of surface-bound proteins that regulate a variety of cell signaling pathways and LAT proteins involved in TCR-mediated signaling.  Malfunction of Ras proteins leads to many forms of cancer and developmental disorders, and there is an urgent need for therapeutic agents to abrogate defective Ras signaling. As part of our broader effort toward developing effective anti-cancer therapeutics by directly targeting Ras, we propose to conduct large-scale molecular dynamics simulations to study the structure, dynamics and druggability of Ras monomers and oligomers in solution and membrane environments. We will also investigate the roles of trans-membrane length, palmitoylation and amino acid sequence in determining membrane domain preferences and dimerization of LAT.
TG-MCB150054.pi_institution: University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston

TG-MCA07S033.name: TG-MCA07S033
TG-MCA07S033.project_abstract:
We request computer resources through the NRAC program so that we are able to take advantage of the recent developments of the Riverside model of the heliosphere and perform numerical analysis of the solar wind - local interstellar medium interaction with the realistic, based on the available observations, boundary conditions. Such resources are the proper venue for our research because it involves not only high-resolution, shock-capturing, 3D solution of MHD equations on adaptive grids, but also direct simulation Monte Carlo (DSMC) modeling of neutral atoms. We propose to advance computational space, astro-, and plasma physics by further developing a new class of computational codes for plasmas and neutral gases that integrates multiple scales and multiple physical processes and descriptions. 
Among these are MHD modeling of plasma, Monte Carlo or multi-fluid modeling of neutral particles, and kinetic modeling of the Galactic cosmic ray transport throughout the heliosphere. The results obtained with our adaptive mesh refinement code will be compared with spacecraft observations and contribute to our understanding the properties of the solar wind plasma and the heliosheath. The code will become publicly available after the end of our science projects.

TG-MCB090159.name: TG-MCB090159
TG-MCB090159.field_of_science: Biochemistry and Molecular Structure and Function
TG-MCB090159.project_abstract: Molecular simulation will be used to investigate the structure of the plant cell wall and the mechanisms by which cellulose-degrading enzymes convert highly recalcitrant plant cell walls into sugars.  Research conducted as part of this proposal will enable molecular-level understanding of the natural routes for cellulose conversion to sugar, thus facilitating rational design approaches for improved biofuels processes at the industrial scale.  Three groups of projects will be pursued concurrently:  1) modeling of the plant cell wall structure from the atomistic to the micrometer length scale with a multiscale simulation approach; 2) investigation of fungal cellulases interacting with cellulose; and 3) a study of bacterial enzymes that assemble to form huge protein complexes (cellulosomes) to degrade cellulose synergistically.

TG-AST030031N.name: TG-AST030031N
TG-AST030031N.project_abstract:
This proposal is for the extension of our numerical investigations of the turbulent magnetic fields in astrophysical plasmas. We are interested in the turbulent mechanisms for the generation and maintenance of fluctuating magnetic fields in stars, galaxies and clusters. 
The physical objective is a detailed understanding of fully developed MHD turbulence both with and without an imposed mean field. In this Renewal Proposal for 2007-08, we ask for a continuation of our allocation to study the magnetic-field generation in systems  with linear shear, the anisotropic Alfven-wave turbulence in the presence of a strong mean field, and the magnetic fluctuations in a model of inhomogeneously interstellar medium. 
The first two projects are of fundamental importance and have many astrophysical applications: accretion flows, galactic fields, turbulence in the solar wind and the inter-stellar medium. The third project addresses a number of recent observational results on the differences between the magnetic-field structure in the galactic spiral arms and in the interarm regions as well as the fundamental problem of turbulent paramagnetism.

TG-DMR070072N.name: TG-DMR070072N
TG-DMR070072N.project_abstract: We propose to apply Teragrid computing resources to investigate oxide and nitride semiconductors, hydrogen storage, and novel CMOS materials. We will apply state-of-art first-principles computational methods based on density functional theory to investigate the atomistic features and the electronic structure of surfaces, interfaces, native defects, and impurities in technologically important oxide and nitride semiconductors, non-classical CMOS materials, and complex hydrides.  Our group has a strong record in the research of wide-band-gap semiconductors, doping and defect physics, semiconductor surfaces and heterojunctions.  There are currently 12 researchers in our group,  including 1 university faculty, 1 project scientist, 1 associate specialist, 4 postdocs, and 5 Ph D students.  Our research is funded by external grants from NSF, DOE, the UCSB Solid State Lighting and Energy Center, the ACS Petroleum Fund and the Semiconductor Research Corporation.  In this proposal we are requesting a total of 1,115,000 Teragrid SUs for the year 2009.

A-pspa.name: A-pspa
A-pspa.project_abstract:
(i) To investigate the possibility of developing a compact CO2 laser-driven particle accelerator based on the newly proposed concept of SWABSiC: surface wave accelerator based on SiC;
to study theoretically and computationally basic accelerator properties of such a structure: its shunt impedance, quality factor, parasitic wakefield modes; to investigate theoretically and experimentally the efficiency of coupling laser radiation into the accelerating surface waves, thermal stability of the proposed SiC-on-Si accelerating structure; to study the possibility of developing a SWABSiC injector of relativistic electrons into a plasma beatwave accelerator;
to investigate the effect of high laser power on the electromagnetic properties of the accelerating
structure; to design the most optimal grating structure for coupling laser energy to beam particles; to study theoretically the dynamics (including wakefield instabilities) of the
accelerated particle beam in this novel structure;
(ii) To investigate laser-plasma acceleration concepts relying on multi-color laser beams, including laser beatwave accelerator in the recently discovered highly nonlinear regime of Dynamical
Bi-Stability; to study the possibility of optimizing the beatwave concept using chirped pulses; to investigate the fundamental physics of propagating multi-color laser beams through
the plasma, including the transverse self-focusing dynamics of multi-color beams; to investigate plasma wakefield generation by femtosecond laser pulse trains obtained using the
recently discovered phenomenon of Electromagnetic Cascading.
(iii) To assess the novel concept of a plasma accelerator based on the novel concept of the Undulator Induced Transparency (UIT) of the plasma at the cyclotron frequency; to threedimensional simulations of wave propagation and particle acceleration in magnetized plasma; to study the efficiency of radiation coupling into this novel accelerating structure; to evaluate the relevance of this concept to proton acceleration.
(iv) To study analytically and numerically the possibility of developing a compact colliding-beam accelerator (CBA), based on a newly developed idea of employing two laser beams counterpropagating in the plasma.

TG-MCA93S028.name: TG-MCA93S028
TG-MCA93S028.project_abstract: During 2005/2006 our group published 31 papers [1-31] and eight reviews [32-39] reporting our LRAC supported research. One paper notably described the first all-atom simulation of an entire virus, showing that some virus capsids assemble around preformed RNA; the reviews covered three fields which have become transformed through advanced computing: membrane transport, cellular mechanics, and bionanotechnology.  Over the past 15 years, we have published more than a hundred molecular dynamics studies, which were cited over 3,100 times. The great impact is very much due to our close link between computational work and experimental work: about half of our 2005/2006 papers were co-authored with experimental collaborators.  Through our own simulations, as well as through simulations of others using our groups program NAMD, the power of NSFs high performance computers is being harnessed daily for mainstream life science. This year, again, all studies proposed by us are linked directly to the laboratory bench, each involving a leading experimental investigator. We seek to continue investigating forefront biology (protein gas conduction, virus infection, DNA loop formation by proteins, mechanosensitive membrane channels, transport through nuclear pores, proteins acting as springs) and to add two ambitious, already well advanced, investigations on bacterial flagella and ribosome, projects which demand simulations of millions of atoms on thousand processors. In addition to all-atom approaches, our studies involve coarse-graining methods that reach beyond 10 microseconds simulation periods. The latter methodology is backed up by six successfully completed investigations [16, 27, 40-43] and heralds a new era in computational biology.

TG-MCB140208.name: TG-MCB140208
TG-MCB140208.field_of_science: Biochemistry and Molecular Structure and Function
TG-MCB140208.project_abstract:
The highly conserved protein phosphatase-1 (PP1) dephosphorylates proteins in all eukaryotic cells. Inhibitor-2 (I2) is an ancient, abundant, and enigmatic PP1 regulatory protein. I2 inhibits PP1 activity, but the PP1-I2 complex can regain phosphatase activity without dissociation after phosphorylation of Thr74 in a 73-residue I2 unstructured domain. Understanding how phosphorylation within the unstructured I2 domain regulates PP1 function is the major focus of this work. Our preliminary data shows that computer molecular dynamic simulations can recapitulate the early steps of phosphorylation-dependent activation of PP1-I2. Data obtained in a XSEDE startup allocation showed that in silico, explicit solvent, phosphorylation-dependent PP1-I2 activation occurred in complexes with human, worm, and yeast I2 orthologs, despite great sequence variations in these I2 orthologs. 
  Our current request has three foci. First, we will explore mechanistic aspects of how I2 Thr74 phosphorylation communicates to the PP1 active site over 20 angstroms away. We will test five overlapping hypotheses by simulating I2 mutants and by artificially altering the dynamics. Second, we will seek an understanding of why particular PP1 mutant proteins are exquisitely dependent on I2 function in yeast. We anticipate these PP1 mutant proteins recruit I2 for folding assistance because they fold poorly by themselves. Thermal denaturation in silico of wild-type and mutant PP1 proteins will explore this contention. Third, accelerated and constant pH molecular dynamics will seek structures of activated, phosphorylated PP1-I2, which require greater time and potentially protonation-dependent conformation changes.

TG-PHY090031.name: TG-PHY090031
TG-PHY090031.project_abstract: New, efficient and scalable approaches to solving the time-dependent Schroedinger equation are developed and applied to the interaction of laser radiation with atoms, molecules and Bose condensates.  We address three important problems; the interaction of short pulse lasers with He, examining the role of electron correlation in single and double electron ejection; the interaction of laser fields with Bose condensates, as described by the time-dependent non-linear Schreodinger equation to create new topological structures such as persistent currents and Josephson junctions and the generalization of the methodology to many-electron atoms such as Ne and Ar.  All of these problems are being actively studied experimentally and require significant computational resources to make further progress.

TG-ATM140005.name: TG-ATM140005
TG-ATM140005.project_abstract:
Computing resources are requested from TAAC on Stampede to perform  1) retrospective decadal climate prediction ensembles over the period 1960-present, and 2) simulations of the externally forced 1850-present climate evolution. The predictions and simulations will be made using Version 2 of the NCEP Climate Forecast System model (CFSv2). The project builds on baseline CFSv2 retrospective decadal prediction ensembles that COLA scientists have recently conducted following the CMIP5 (Coupled Model Intercomparison Project Version 5) protocols, using ocean initial conditions over the period 1960 to 2008 from the NEMOVAR-COMBINE observational analysis. The decadal forecast version of CFSv2 is one of the highest resolution models participating in the CMIP5 decadal prediction experiments. However, in the course of the baseline experiments, large model biases were documented, and a serious code error was discovered. 

We are proposing to first conduct the retrospective prediction ensembles using the model with the code error corrected, and to replace the existing CFSv2 decadal predictions in the CMIP5 database with the corrected forecasts. Despite the code correction, biases remain in the CFSv2 climate, including rapid disappearance of the sea ice, collapse of the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC), and unrealistic structures in the sea surface temperature and salinity climatologies. Physically-based code modifications have been developed that substantially reduce the sea ice melting biases, and work is underway to understand and eliminate the AMOC collapse and other biases. The proposed computations include a second set of retrospective forecasts ensembles with the sea ice correction introduced, and a third retrospective set including all model improvements as well as an expanded set of initial conditions. The forecast ensembles will be carried out both with and without the specified external forcing due to volcanic aerosols  with volcanic forcing, since this is the standard experiment for CMIP5 model intercomparison, and without volcanic forcing in order to remove the artificial prediction skill introduced by specifying unpredictable forcing. 

As well as decadal prediction ensembles, historical runs are needed to attribute the decadal prediction skill to either the contributions from external forcing or initialized internal variability. The proposed simulations include an ensemble of all-corrections historical simulations of the 1850-present climate evolution with all external forcings applied.

TG-AST150003.name: TG-AST150003
TG-AST150003.project_abstract: How do galaxies get the gas which sustains star formation over cosmic time? Motivated by recent observations of magnetic fields in clouds falling in to the Milky Way from the Galactic halo, we propose to address the role of magnetic fields in controlling inflow into galaxies to test whether magnetic fields enable infalling gas to reach the disk, condense, and join the star formation reservoir. We will accomplish this by adding infalling clouds to the PI's Flash setup which uses supernovae to establish a vertically-stratified, turbulent, multi-phase interstellar medium. We will trace the evolution of these inflowing clouds with a variety of magnetic field configurations in both the disk and the clouds, comparing the results to observations of magnetized Milky Way halo clouds. The models will predict the extent to which gas from these clouds mixes with the interstellar medium in the disk, where future star formation will occur.

TG-MCB090003.name: TG-MCB090003
TG-MCB090003.field_of_science: Biochemistry and Molecular Structure and Function
TG-MCB090003.project_abstract: Multiple projects related to the modeling of biomolecular systems are proposed. 1) Molecular dynamics simulations of MutS and MSH2-MSH6, large proteins involved in DNA mismatch recognition and the initiation of repair, would provide a detailed mechanistic understanding of how damaged DNA is recognized and how that recognition leads to the initiation of downstream repair events. In particular, simulations would compare the effect of different nucleotides bound to the ATPase domains and the effect of binding to regular DNA vs. mismatched DNA and no DNA. 2) In order to understand regulation of sarcoplasmic reticulum Ca2+-ATPase (SERCA) by phospholamban (PLB) at the molecular level, replica exchange implicit membrane simulations of the SERCA-PLB complex are proposed. Such simulations would provide information about the interaction of PLB with SERCA as a function of PLB phosphorylation and as a function of SERCA state (active E1 vs. inactive E2 form). 3) As part of efforts to develop an intermediate-level coarse-grained model of proteins that is ultimately targeted at protein structure refinement, a series of long test simulations of selected proteins are proposed. Thsee simulations would allow extensive testing and further improvements of an initial version of the coarse-grained model.

TG-MCB140281.name: TG-MCB140281
TG-MCB140281.project_abstract:
High-throughput approaches which illuminate the epigenetic basis of human disease are widely anticipated to usher in a new era of information-based precision medicine, with broad applications in basic research, clinical diagnostics, and treatment.  The central objective of my lab's research is to develop novel bioinformatic methods that identify the type and boundaries of all varieties of active functional elements.  We also seek to apply these tools to understand the basis of gene regulation.

We foresee two key goals to be addressed in the next year:
  Develop and optimize a machine learning approach, based on artificial neural networks, that accurately classifies the type of epigenetic element using functional genomic data.  

  We have used a genomic assay called PRO-seq to map functional elements in CD4+ T-cells isolated from humans, chimpanzees, and rhesus macaques. These maps provide a rich source of data profiling both expression levels, and the location and activity of regulatory elements across 25 million years of primate evolution. Using this data, we hope to understand how differences in gene expression arise from changes in DNA sequence, and how evolutionary pressures have shaped the human adaptive immune system during the last 25 million years.

TG-DMR110058.name: TG-DMR110058
TG-DMR110058.project_abstract: We request an allocation of 2.5 million service units on TeraGrid resources, principally Steele, Lonestar, and KIDS to perform the search for materials, nanoparticles and surfaces with desired properties using hybrid evolutionary approach and phase transition investigation. The structures, properties and phase transition pathway of the solid phases in the Fe-O and Mg-F systems will be studied. The main goal of the project is to predict the phase transition mechanism in Fe-O and Mg-F systems under high pressure and temperature. Central to this project is the PIs USPEX code (including evolutionary algorithm, metadynamics method, the VC-NEB method and TPS approach), interfaced with first-principles electronic structure calculations. This approach has already given many interesting predictions confirmed by experiment. Our calculations will be performed with the widely used ab-initio VASP code. The properties of the stable and metastable structures obtained in this project will be studied and promising new functional materials will be identified. These calculations, in addition to providing practically important results, will also allow us to test the concept of hybrid global optimization, where global optimization with respect to a desired property (for example hardness) is conducted in the space of local minima of the (free) energy.
