We present VASP scaling measurements on Abe (similar to Steele, Lonestar). Our request of 2.5 million SUs will enable the structural prediction and phase transition pathway investigation in the Fe-O and Mg-F systems.

TG-MCA94P018.name: TG-MCA94P018
TG-MCA94P018.project_abstract:
With both a massively parallel gravity/SPH code and ``embarrassingly
parallel'' dynamical simulations, we will to study problems on vastly
different scales: from the formation of the Oort cloud of comets in
our solar system to the collapse of the largest gravitationally bound
structures in the Universe.  On cosmological scales, we will extend
our previous high resolution simulations of galaxy formation by
focusing on the spiral galaxy scaling relations (e.g. the Tully-Fisher
relation) between galaxy mass, as determined by rotation velocity, and
morphological properties of the galaxy such as disk scale lengths and
bulge to disk ratios.  We will take a multi pronged approach to this
problem.  First we will continue our campaign of high resolution
simulations of individual galaxies in their cosmological context using
a ``zoom-in'' technique.  Our focus here will be trying to understand
the origin of ``bulgeless galaxies'' which we have not been able to
simulate thus far.  Secondly we will perform a simulation of a
cosmological volume at moderate resolution in order to get a fair
sample in order to more directly compare with observational surveys.
Lastly, we will focus particular attention to our Local Group of
galaxies by performing a simulation with initial conditions
constrained by observations of the nearby large scale structure.  This
will be similar to our ``zoomed-in'' galaxies except the focus will be
on Andromeda, the Milky Way and the surrounding structure.

On galactic scales we will continue to study the formation of the
outer regions of disks via interactions with bars and spiral density
waves.  Our emphasis this year will be on including more cosmological
context in these studies.  We will be including local and cosmic UV
background flux, and will be including interactions with other
structure via mergers.  We will also be looking at this phenomenon in
lower mass galaxies.  Our study of the morphological transformation of
disks in clusters will continue by looking at a variety of galaxy
models as they fall into and interact with a galaxy cluster.

On planetary scales, we will study the formation of the Oort cloud as
a function of the galactic environment in of the early Solar System.
Whether the Sun was part of an open cluster in the early stages of
planet formation effects the distribution of the comet cloud, and
thereby determines the frequency and strength of subsequent comet
showers.

We will also be continue performing scaling tests of our recently publicly released parallel N-body code, ChaNGa.

Alloys.name: Alloys
Alloys.project_abstract: We are interested in developing a better understanding of the properties of bimetallic or trimetallic core-shell nanostructures as catalysts for the reduction of oxygen in acid medium. Under these conditions, the metal catalysts may undergo a side corrosion reaction where the metal particles may dissolve into the acid medium. We have recently developed a methodology for testing the durability of Pt-based alloys via computational determination of the electrochemical potential shift with respect to pure platinum. For this, we use the VASP program to compute the surface chemical potential of slab systems. The calculations are done with and without the presence of adsorbed atomic oxygen.

TG-DMR130042.name: TG-DMR130042
TG-DMR130042.project_abstract: The interactions between gold nanoparticles (AuNPs) functionalized with designed surface monolayers must be understood to enable the creation of a new generation of drug delivery vehicles and biosensors. The difficulty of visualizing the membrane interface using traditional experimental methods, however, has made the study of such interactions difficult to understand. Computational and theoretical methods have emerged as a critical tool for understanding interactions at the biological interface due to the development of force fields and simulation methods able to model such interactions in atomistic detail. In this work, we request XSEDE resources to study the interactions between a particular class of anionic, monolayer-protected AuNPs and cellular membranes using a combination of atomistic and coarse-grained molecular dynamics simulations. The AuNPs we intend to study have been shown experimentally to non-specifically, non-disruptively penetrate into cellular membranes via a non-endocytotic process without disrupting cell function. Understanding this unique mechanism will lead to rules governing the design of a new class of powerful drug delivery vehicle. We propose to use atomistic simulations to model the role of lipids and specific lipid interactions with the particles of interest, then complement these simulations with coarse-grained simulations to obtain the potential of mean force for bilayer translocation. All simulations will aim to elucidate the role that monolayer composition and structure play in the penetration process. Our multiscale approach will yield high impact results and shine light on a puzzling mechanism with implications in a variety of fields.

TG-DMR130047.name: TG-DMR130047
TG-DMR130047.project_abstract: Oxidation kinetics is critical toward quantitative life-prediction of metal and alloys. Generally oxidation involves complex coupling between chemical reaction, charge interaction and mass transport and these processes may take different roles at different length/time scales. Usually mass transport in oxidation inevitably involves microstructural effects with growth of oxide film. These problems typically have time and length scales far beyond the capability of atomistic level simulation approaches. As a mesoscale simulation approach, phase field method has unique strength in modeling material kinetics and microstructural effects. Based on the readily developed phase field oxidation model on pure metals (through the startup allocation from XSEDE), the PI proposes to perform extensive study on microstructure dependence of metal oxidation. Furthermore, oxidation model for alloys will be developed and the free energy functions are to be imported from standard thermodynamic database. The model is aimed at realistic prediction for oxidation kinetics for at least binary alloys.

FDTD3D-Cont.name: FDTD3D-Cont
FDTD3D-Cont.project_abstract:
In now-completed projects (FDTD3D, TG-DMS080033N), the PI conducted large-scale tests of the IWAVE simulation package. This package has been used to benchmark synthetic data for the SEAM project, a multicompany oil industry consortium. The SEAM data will be made available for use by the entire geophysical research community; it is considerably larger (and closer to contemporary field data dimensions) and has much greater physical fidelity than prior benchmark data sets. Our role was to verify its accuracy. In the course of our work with SEAM, considerably assisted by the projects at TACC, my group (re)discovered significant flaws in the standard simulation technology (regular grid finite difference methods) and began working to overcome these deficiencies. Iwave itself, while quite conservative, represents the first public domain seismic simulator with high-order stencils, efficient absorbing boundary conditions, and both message-passing and thread--based parallelism demonstrated to scale well to hundreds of cores. Iwave will be released at the upcoming SEG meeting and published by the SEG.

The current request asks for sufficient resources to carry on the prior work in several directions:

(1) together with several students, I have developed an object-oriented wrapper around Iwave to produce the various components of data-fitting model estimation (known as full waveform inversion in reflection seismology) along with several other techniques in imaging (reverse time migration) and novel inversion methods (nonlinear velocity analysis). These applications require testing at a scale not available in my lab.

(2) the spin-off project to enhance simulation accuracy fhrough efficient structured-mesh finite element modeling has achieved its goal in one case already, namely constant density acoustics (to be presented fpr the first time at the SEG 2009 meeting). The main feature is the necessity of capturing subgrid features in the model in upscaled stiffness and mass matrix coefficients. I have proposed a method for upscaling in teh special case of constant density acoustics which requires the coefficient field to be represented by spatial multiresolution (wavelet expansion). This representation dovetails with inversion methodology - if successful it will alter the way in which models are constructed in this field. Once again, large scale tests are a necessity for this new application of Iwave.

(3) both as part of my own research program and to support Phase II of the SEAM project, I have begun to construct an elastic modeling capability within the Iwave framework. The computational complexity is an order of magnitude greater than acoustics, and large-scale testing will be necessary earlier in the process.

TG-MCA95C006.name: TG-MCA95C006
TG-MCA95C006.project_abstract: The Center for Analysis and Prediction of Storms CAPS), a graduated NSF S&T center, continues to maintain a vibrant program of basic and applied research in storm-scale data assimilation and numerical weather prediction (NWP).  CAPS leads the University of Oklahomas participation as a core research partner in an NSF Engineering Research Center (ERC) for Collaborative Adaptive Sensing of Atmosphere (CASA).  CAPS also leads an multi-institution NSF Large Information Technology Research (ITR) project, known as Linked Environments for Atmospheric Discovery (LEAD), that seeks to develop an infrastructure for mesoscale meteorology research and education. Other funded projects include storm-scale data assimilation centered around ensemble Kalman filter and variational data assimilation (DA), and those that seek the understanding of convective storm and tornado dynamics and of initial condition sensitivity through very-large-ensemble approach, the study on the impacts of special data sources. Extension will also be made to study hurricane track and intensity forecasts and their sensitivity to initial and boundary conditions. The grants that supported the research for which supercomputing time is sought in this proposal are listed in the cover page. As a continuation of the experiments of 2007, CAPS seeks resources to perform realtime storm-scale ensemble prediction with increased sophistication that is supported by LEAD and CSTAR grants, and to produce realtime numerical prediction of thunderstorms assimilating data from the CASA radar network. The latter is essential to fulfill the mission of NSF ERC CASA program. In addition, on-demand forecasts will be performed by LEAD across the Teragrid resources. A combined total of 2,576,200 service units (SUs) across LRAC computing platforms is requested.

TG-DMS080016N.name: TG-DMS080016N
TG-DMS080016N.project_abstract:
Storm surge is caused by wind, atmospheric pressure gradients, tides,
river flow and short-crested wind-waves.  An accurate numerical model
of storm surge should account for all of these effects.  Such a model
can be used in predictive mode as storms approach landfall for the
purposes of emergency evacuation and response, and can be used in the
design and implementation of improved man-made and natural protection
systems for vulnerable coastal areas.  Storm surge computer models
have been developed extensively over the past decade; however, only
within the past few years have the algorithms, computational power and
resolution been available to begin to model these events with any
reasonable degree of accuracy.


The goal of this project is to investigate the use of petascale
computing to significantly advance the state-of-the-art in storm surge
simulation, to accurately model flows at multiple, interacting scales,
at resolution never before attempted, and to demonstrate that results
from these simulations can be delivered in real-time to emergency
managers.  To achieve this goal will require the continued development
and improved understand of the mechanisms involved in tightly coupled
models of wind, waves, circulation and geomorphology, improvements in
the description of the physical domain and adaptive resolution of all
energetic flow scales, and investigation of accurate, robust and
highly parallelizable numerical algorithms.  Efficient implementation
of these models on emerging petascale architectures will require
utilizing the latest developments in parallel data management,
real-time visualization, and programming tools.

In this project we will develop high resolution, large-scale coastal
inundation models discretized using robust and highly parallelizable
algorithms. The models will be implemented on NSF Track 2 HPC systems
currently under development.
TG-DMS080016N.pi_institution: Institute for Computational Engineering and Science

TG-OCE140024.name: TG-OCE140024
TG-OCE140024.project_abstract:
The NSF Science & Technology Center for Coastal Margin Observation & Prediction (CMOP) is studying the Columbia River estuary as a river-dominated bioreactor, where biogeochemical transformations occur disproportionately through specialized biological hotspots (e.g., lateral bays, estuarine turbidity maxima, and red water blooms). Anchoring the study is an observation network with high-resolution endurance stations, mobile platforms, and process-oriented campaigns. A family of interdisciplinary models has been developed iteratively, with the benefit of calibration/validation against the CMOP data set, and the frequent scrutiny of process-oriented investigators. These models have been ported to the XSEDE environment (through separate specific allocations to CMOP post-docs and students), and are routinely run there for development, calibration, skill assessment and sensitivity simulations. 
Here, we will use mature versions of these models to provide an integrated view of circulation and sediment dynamics, preparatory of net ecosystem metabolism (NEM) simulations in the estuary. We will also examine the estuarys susceptibility to change. Simulations for the contemporary estuary will typically cover periods over a decade, at high-resolution (time step of 36 seconds, saved every 15 minutes). For one of those years, ten scenarios of globally and locally induced change will also be conducted. 
We will map our simulation results onto a modern estuarine classification system, to characterize the dependence of the estuary on the four prevailing physical regimes in the estuary, which are driven by river flows and tides. We will also characterize major ocean influences (as measured by salinity intrusion) relative to the estuarine regimes and coastal-upwelling regimes. By exploring select scenarios of change, we will characterize the susceptibility of the estuarine regimes to evolving external forcing and bathymetry.
This silico analysis will constitute a major advancement in our iterative understanding of a very complex estuary. The analysis will be limited by the modeling skill, which itself depends on the prevailing forcing and estuarine regimes. An extensive modeling skill assessment will be conducted, whichtogether with a rich and diversity observational data setwill be used to assess strengths and weaknesses of the analysis.

TG-AST130007.name: TG-AST130007
TG-AST130007.project_abstract: We propose to run a set of hydrodynamic cosmological simulations that include a complete treatment of galaxy formation physics together with Self-Interacting Dark Matter (SIDM). With them we will search for a solution to the discrepancy between the observed dark matter central densities in galaxies and galaxy clusters, and those predicted by our standard model of cosmological structure formation. For this we will explore the phenomenological consequences of two qualitatively different classes of solutions: self-interacting dark matter and stellar feedback. Our work will contribute to our understanding on how baryons transform the central structure of dark matter halos, how self-interacting dark matter affects galaxy formation, and what are the resulting central densities of dark matter halos when self-interacting dark matter acts together with baryonic processes. We will provide the best constraints available on how strong can dark matter self-interact, and demonstrate if SIDM is a viable solution to the small scale problems that challenge our standard CDM paradigm.

TG-OCE140020.name: TG-OCE140020
TG-OCE140020.project_abstract: Water mass transport and mixing over continental slopes are critical to coastal marine ecosystems and global transports of heat and salt, and an increasing number of studies indicate that these processes depend sensitively on the properties of mesoscale turbulence over steep topography. Global ocean simulations will remain unable to resolve these flows for decades to come, particularly at high latitudes, and therefore require an effective parametrization of eddy mixing and transport over continental slopes. Yet despite major recent advances in parametrization strategies for mesoscale eddies, there have been no concerted attempts to adopt such strategies to continental slopes. This project aims to develop and evaluate a parametrization for ocean mesoscale eddy transport and mixing over continental slopes. To accomplish this we propose to develop a suite of high-resolution, eddy-resolving process simulations encompassing a range of continental shelf/slope and surface wind/buoyancy forcing configurations, including a passive diffusivity tracer to quantify mixing. We plan to conduct these simulations using the MIT general circulation model (MITgcm), though we may use alternative ocean modelling systems such as the Regional Ocean Modeling System (ROMS) or the Hallberg Isopycnal Model (HIM) if they prove to be more computationally efficient. We will also use this suite of simulations to characterize more general properties of mesoscale turbulence over steep continental slopes, such as the routes to dissipation of surface-input momentum and energy, sources and generation of eddy kinetic energy in slope currents, and constraints on the inverse energy cascade and jet formation. The proposed simulations are computationally intensive because a large computational grid will be required to resolve the small lengthscales of baroclinic eddy formation over continental slopes, particularly at high latitudes. Based on comparable previous simulations, we calculate that each simulation will require 10,000 CPU hours. In order to cover development, testing and production runs over a sufficiently large range of model configurations, we will require the full allocation of 200,000 compute hours.

TG-CTS160011.name: TG-CTS160011
TG-CTS160011.project_abstract: Selective oxidation is an important chemical reaction to produce fine chemicals from alkanes, alkenes and alcohols. In our work, we use Kegging Polyoxometalates (POMs) as our model catalysts to investigate the reaction mechanism of selective oxidation of methanol and to further elucidate the structure-function relationship in heterogeneous catalysis. To achieve these goals, we rigorously combine experiments and Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations, which is allowed by well-known structure of POMs and the availability of diverse compositions of POMs with a same structure. We have found that selective oxidation of methanol follows a molecular route, rather than dissociative route, based on our DFT calculations and kinetic and isotopic experiments. We further elucidated an accurate descriptor to describe a relationship between H-addition energy of POM (HAE) and the rate limiting reduction step.  Based on these results, we want to move further to understand the reaction mechanism of the re-oxidation process to close the catalytic cycle. The re-oxidation process, however, cannot be easily accessed from steady-state experiments as the re-oxidation steps are faster than reduction within the redox cycle. Instead, we will probe the re-oxidation pathways and relevant transition states by performing detailed DFT calculations. The proposed reaction mechanism will be further proved by time-dependent DFT along with transition UV-Vis experiments which can provide dynamics of reduced centers based on the pre-edge features of POMs.

A-ti8.name: A-ti8
A-ti8.project_abstract: Recent development of diffuse-interface modeling has led to new oppurnities for solving complex thermally-coupled multicomponent multiphase flows. This modeling technique enjoys solid mathematical and thermodynamic foundations. Owing to that, this new methodology may properly avoid unnecessary numerically artifical procedures that have plagued most current multiphase flow solvers. The objective of this research is to develop a computational framework that addresses interesting and important multiphase flow problems, such as boiling flows, cavitating flows, etc. We have gained an initial success in simulating boiling flows, and the result can be previewed in ICES research album https://www.flickr.com/photos/icesut/14992969345/ We believe this is time to perform deeper investigations in this direction and the methodology will have significant impacts on physics and engineering.
A-ti8.pi_institution: Department of Aerospace Engineering and Engineering Mechanics

TG-MCB110140.name: TG-MCB110140
TG-MCB110140.project_abstract: This proposal requests CPU time on the XSEDE facilities, particularly the Gordon Compute Cluster (Gordon) at the San Diego Supercomputer Center or the Cray XT5 (Kraken) at the National Institute for Computational Sciences. The proposed research involves rigorous measurements of affinities for small molecules binding to membrane proteins. The methods will involve the highly scalable atomistic molecular dynamics code NAMD and sophisticated methods for calculating free energies. Research will be carried out in a recently formed research group at the Center for Computational and Integrative Biology, and is currently funded by the NSF and NIH.

TG-ATM140033.name: TG-ATM140033
TG-ATM140033.project_abstract:
A complete understanding of the way prominent modes of Atlantic and Pacific climate variability influence Atlantic tropical cyclone (TC) activity is valuable in mitigating the impacts of tropical cyclones.  North Atlantic and El Nino-Southern Oscillation (ENSO)-related tropical Pacific sea surface temperature (SST) variability strongly influences Atlantic tropical cyclone activity.  However, although the location of maximum SST warming during El Nino events varies from the Central to East tropical Pacific, all El Nino types have been conventionally considered together in assessing their influence on Atlantic TCs.   In order to completely understand the impact of El Nino on Atlantic TCs, we must account for East Pacific and Central Pacific El Nino separately.  Little research has been conducted on this problem, using limited observational records and producing conflicting results; we propose investigating this topic with idealized tropical channel model simulations at 15 km horizontal resolution.  The modeling experiments overcome the brevity and complexity of the observational record by cleanly isolating the influence of Atlantic and Pacific SST from factors which also influence Atlantic TC activity, while the high-resolution permits an evaluation of not only TC frequency, but also TC intensity.  
In addition, recent research suggests tropical Atlantic SST influences Atlantic TCs more strongly than northern tropical Atlantic SST alone; this research will examine the mechanisms by which variability in the tropical Atlantic SST meridional gradient, characterized by the Atlantic Meridional Mode, influences Atlantic TC activity with idealized tropical channel model simulations.  Finally, we investigate how the modes of tropical Pacific and Atlantic SST variability interact in their influence on Atlantic TC activity and the atmospheric environment in the TC development region using both observations and model simulations.  This perspective, which considers Pacific and Atlantic modes of variability in combination, will provide a more complete understanding of Atlantic TC variability.  The knowledge gained by this research can be applied to reduce uncertainty in seasonal forecasts and climate change projections of Atlantic tropical cyclone activity.

tagmap.name: tagmap
tagmap.project_abstract: Gene expression reflects physiological state of organism, and also has a considerable genetic component to its variation that reflect the history of evolutionary adaptation. Profiling genome-wide gene expression is therefore of great interest for ecology and evolutionary biology. However, this research is constrained by the lack of suitable platform (such as microarrays) in most organisms used as models in these areas of biology. Our goal is to develop a platform-less gene expression profiling methodology, thereby straightforwardly applicable to any organism, based solely on next-generation sequencing. The two principal stages of the methodogy are (i) assembling of sequence database through transcriptome sequencing using 454; and (ii) digital gene expression profiling by means of short-tag sequencing (SOLiD or Illumina), utilizing the 454 data as a mapping reference. In particular, the mapping procedure in the existing form turns out to be very computationally intensive: it consumed 50,000 SU's on a small-scale test (TACC time contributed by Scott Hunicke-Smith). We would like to request 100,000 SU’s to finish the project, while we are seeking to refine/improve the computational methods.

PIV_Errors.name: PIV_Errors
PIV_Errors.project_abstract: This project will utilize high fidelity computational fluid dynamics (CFD) calculations to generate synthetic experimental data. This database will then be used to understand errors in laser-based flow diagnostics. The CFD data will be generated using the UTcomp multipurpose CFD code developed by Prof. Raman's group. The focus here is on experiments designed to study shock-turbulence interactions in canonical flow configurations. The UTcomp code is highly scalable and has been demonstrated to be efficient on 1024-2048 processors for problem sizes being considered here. The computational time will enable a range of flow conditions to be generated, which will help understand experimental measurement errors in challenging flow conditions. The postprocessing the database to generate the synthetic images and analysis of the flow volume will be carried out on TACC systems as well as local clusters available to us.
PIV_Errors.pi_institution: Department of Aerospace Engineering and Engineering Mechanics

TG-DMR970008S.name: TG-DMR970008S
TG-DMR970008S.project_abstract: Our group studies the structural, thermodynamic, kinetic, electronic, and electrochemical properties of materials for energy technologies with a focus on the ab initio prediction for complex materials. Using our grant from last year, we accomplished most of what we outlined as a plan of research in last year's proposal, and submitted several papers based on that work: 1) we have determined the equilibrium particle shapes for olivine structure LiFePO4 and LiMnPO4 and calculated the energy barriers for lithium in the bulk region to diffuse out at the (010) surface. These factors control the morphology and performance of this important class of Li ion battery cathode materials. 2) We have calculated the bending strain energy, defect energy and interfacial energy in TiS2 nanotubes, and determined the optimal bending angle. These calculations permit a better understanding of the structure of inorganic nanotubes, which is crucial to accurate calculations of their electrochemical and other properties for Li ion battery applications. 3) We constructed the Pourbaix diagrams for both bulk and 0.5 to 2 nm diameter Pt nanoparticles, which helps us understand and improve the stability of Pt nanocatalysts. 4) We developed a method based on the cluster expansion formalism that makes highly accurate thermodynamic calculations of nano-structured materials computationally feasible, and applied it successfully to our test system of Au-Pd nanoparticles to predict ground state structures. This method allows us to extend our computational work to alloyed nanoparticles that are too large for the fully ab initio approach. We are requesting an allocation to allow us to advance our studies on several areas: in Li ion battery materials we will 1) continue the study of LiFePO4 nanoparticles with adsorbates to study how the equilibrium particle morphology is modified by different solution environments and predict optimal synthesis conditions, and 2) study lithiation reactions in alloyed metallic and oxide nanoparticles. 3) In fuel cell catalysis we will investigate the effects of alloying on Pt catalysts. 4) We will also evaluate different quantum mechanical, continuum and hybrid model in the study of electrochemical properties of room temperature ionic liquids for electrolyte and other applications. 5) We will evaluate the optical and transport properties of candidate materials for photovoltaic applications using the GW approximation. The amount of units we are requesting this year is higher than last year's allocation because of the fact that we are expanding our research program to include additional areas of energy technologies and also because of the increased complexity in our calculations.

TG-MCA99S024.name: TG-MCA99S024
TG-MCA99S024.project_abstract:
We propose to continue and expand our study of several astrophysical problems using well tested, publically available astrophysical simulation codes. We will continue our use of the
slab-parellelized, high-order, finite difference, non-ideal MHD code Pencil (developed by A. Brandenburg & W. Dobler), to study the
interaction of planets with partially-ionized protostellar disks, as well as the magnetorotational instability in such disks.  We will also continue to use the parallel, adaptive mesh refinement (AMR) hydrocode Flash (developed by the ASCI Flash center at the U. of Chicago) to study the formation of superwinds in local models of a supernova-driven, turbulent interstellar medium. Finally, we will continue a project begun elsewhere to model early generations of star formation in the universe using the parallel, smoothed particle hydrodynamics code GADGET 2 (developed by V. Springel and collaborators).

TG-TRA160006.name: TG-TRA160006
TG-TRA160006.project_abstract: This allocation will be used to help the researchers at Clark Atlanta University to understand the XSEDE resources and to run simple or test calculations.

TG-MCB130173.name: TG-MCB130173
TG-MCB130173.project_abstract: Bacteria possess a number of elements and systems that are either completely unique or distinct from their higher-order eukaryotic counterparts.  For example, Gram-negative bacteria possess a second, outer membrane surrounding them that is composed not only of phospholipids but also the unusual lipopolysaccharides.  How this outer-membrane's composition affects embedded proteins within or diffusion of small molecules across it are often neglected questions in most computational studies to date.  Addressing these questions at the atomic scale is one of the major goals of this proposal.  For comparison and validation, studies investigating diffusion of small molecules as well as partitioning of small protein helices in traditional phospholipid membranes are proposed.  Another distinct system is the bacterial ribosome, which is the target of a large fraction of antibiotics known as macrolides that interfere with polypeptide synthesis by blocking its exit tunnel.  By determining the structures and interactions of nascent proteins within the exit tunnel, with and without bound macrolides, as proposed here, the precise role of the exit tunnel in protein synthesis will be illuminated.  Furthermore, these studies will permit the rational design of new macrolides and macrolide derivatives.  The primary technique to be used for all studies is molecular dynamics simulations with the highly scalable program NAMD.

TG-MCB070073N.name: TG-MCB070073N
TG-MCB070073N.field_of_science: Biochemistry and Molecular Structure and Function
TG-MCB070073N.project_abstract:
200,000 supplement SU's are requested for the following molecular simulations:
1.  Docking, equilibration, and free energy calculations of insulin and insulin-like growth factor (IGF) type 1 on the on the IGF-1 receptor.
2.  Development of a novel non-equilibrium simulation of "conformational diffusion" in the acetylcholine-gated ion channel.
3.  Targeted molecular dynamics simulations of conformational changes in the HIV-1 gp120 envelope protein.

TG-AST050012N.name: TG-AST050012N
TG-AST050012N.project_abstract: The tilt between the black hole and disk angular momenta in accretion disk systems is an often overlooked free parameter. Our group has done the only fully relativistic MHD simulations of tilted disks around rapidly rotating black holes, and we've made some very interesting discoveries. With the current proposal we plan to extend our earlier work in 2 key ways: testing a wider range of spins and testing thinner disks. The wider range of spins is to explore how the orientation of jets are affected by the spin of the black hole and tilt of the disk. Testing thinner disks is important because of the interplay between the disk thickness and the vertical shear in the disk in determining its structure. In order to accomplish these goals we request 465,000 SU of computing time in the form of a Medium Resource Allocation Grant.

Rate-Dependent-TSR.name: Rate-Dependent-TSR
Rate-Dependent-TSR.project_abstract:
Extracting traction-separation relationships for cracks/interfaces in both viscoelastic and elastic media can be equivalently described as solving a Cauchy inverse boundary value problem. Briefly put, an inverse Cauchy problem is usually described as a problem whose boundary is made up of an over-constrained component, where both Dirichlet and Neumann conditions are given on the same part of the boundary, an under-constrained component, where neither Dirichlet nor Neumann boundary conditions are prescribed and a well-defined component, where either Dirichlet or Neumann boundary conditions are specified to complete the problem. 
In this work, for a given far field loading condition, a framework is proposed to independently solve for the tractions and displacements governing the interface/crack in elastic media. The proposed framework combines the field projection method  and an iterative method to solve Cauchy problems with a regularization effect to numerically derive formulas that can be utilized to measure tractions and displacements. This framework only utilizes the complete displacement and load measurements made on the accessible part of the boundary. Furthermore, using correspondence principles, an extension is developed which can be used to solve a similar problem for a body exhibiting viscoelastic behavior.
Rate-Dependent-TSR.pi_institution: Center for Mechanics of Solids, Structure, and Materials

TBI.name: TBI
TBI.project_abstract:
Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is a significant health concern. Due to the large number of injuries that occur each year, the decreased quality of life caused by the victim’s disability, and the increased medical cost, there is a great need for designing therapeutic treatments to alleviate the long-term effects of TBI. However, no drugs are currently approved for treatment of TBI. Here, we propose to design positive allosteric modulators (PAMs) targeting alpha7 nicotinic acetylcholine receptor (alpha7-nAChR) for TBI treatment.

Our preliminary study has shown that administration of alpha7-nAChR type II PAM PNU-120596 post-TBI in young adult rats improved TBI-induced cognitive dysfunction and has both neuroprotective and anti-inflammatory effects. We hypothesize that alpha7-nAChR has multiple allosteric sites binding to distinct types of allosteric modulators and Type II PAMs have high therapeutic potential for TBI treatment.  The specific aims are 1) to delineation of allosteric mechanisms of action of Type I/II PAMs; and 2) to identification of novel Type II PAMs.

We will use a combination of in-house developed computational tools to model the structure of the a7-nAChR channel and detect networks of residues that could be involved in long-range interactions via an allosteric mechanism. The identified allosteric networks will be used to identify sites that are exposed to the solvent and thus accessible to small molecules. Known allosteric Type I/II PAMs will be probed for interactions with these sites to distinct Type II allosteric sites from Type I allosteric sites. Molecular dynamics simulations will be performed to understand the distinct mechanisms of action of Type I/II PAMs. We will use ligand-based and structure based virtual screening to identify novel drug-like small molecules that could bind to Type II allosteric sites. We will then perform simulations of the bound and unbound states of the receptor channel to verify that these molecules can allosterically affect the function of the alpha7-nAChR channel. At the end of this project, up to 80 commercially available compounds identified by virtual screening will be purchased and tested for their potential Type II PAMs properties in electrophysiological patch-clamp experiments.
TBI.pi_institution: University of North Texas - Health Science Center

TG-CTS160008.name: TG-CTS160008
TG-CTS160008.project_abstract: Nanostructured materials, which constitute a subject for one of the frontier areas of materials science and technology, present numerous technological challenges for synthesis, separation, processing, handling, and analysis due to the small characteristic length-scales.  In this present collaboration, we use modeling and theoretical techniques for obtaining molecular insight into two specific applications: (1) Structure and dynamics of bile salt surfactants and their counter-ions in the vicinity of aqueous single-walled carbon nanotube suspensions and (2) Thermo-mechanics of Spirolactam-based Probe Molecules in Polymeric Materials.  Our interest in these two specific areas is motivated by the results from experiments by our collaborators and colleagues at NIST.  We propose to use the requested allocation on Stampede to use the LAMMPS software package for molecular dynamics simulations and the NWChem software package for density-functional theory based modeling of relevant models, both of which are currently used on the Stampede cluster.  Our preliminary results provide robust support to our choice of techniques for the two projects.  Molecular insight obtained from this modeling effort is critical for refining the interpretation of the existing experimental results and further the metrology of nanostructured soft materials.

TG-CTS070018N.name: TG-CTS070018N
TG-CTS070018N.project_abstract:
The main objective of the proposed research is to develop, verify, and validate an integrated multiscale model for the
investigation of variable density two-phase flows in complex environments. A novel numerical technique based on combination of a particle-based method and standard continuum approach will be developed to study interfacial phenomena of inception, growth and bursting of vapor bubbles, breakup and coalescence of liquid droplets, and interactions of the fluid surface with complex solid boundaries encountered in cooling of electronic devices, hydro-mechanics of propulsion systems, and cavitation.

Numerical modeling of these flow features using traditional mesh-based finite-volume schemes necessitates use of a time-varying adaptive grid to capture the wide range of length and time scales. The increased complexity and associated costs related to the topological changes in the computational grid are absent in the pure mesh-free techniques. However, they suffer from issues related to efficient implementation of advanced multi-physics models. The hybrid computational approach merges the locally `adaptive' nature of the mesh-free approach for interface tracking with the relative `ease' of the Eulerian finite-volume formulation for complex configurations providing an efficient and accurate numerical technique. 

The proposed developments will be performed in an existing unstructured grid finite-volume solver capable of performing large-scale computations of turbulent flows in complex configurations.
This solver was developed under the Department of Energy's Advanced Scientific Computing (ASC) program at Stanford University. %The PI was part of this program from 2000-2005 and has demonstrated high efficiency and speedup of the solver. 
The basic algorithm will be further developed to address simulations of turbulent flows at high Reynolds numbers. A number of verification and validation studies on motion of single and multiple particles in turbulent flows is planned. Once completed, this formulation will be used to study particle-turbulence interactions using direct numerical simulation. Interactions of micro-bubbles with turbulent boundary layers is important for drag reduction,  whereas studying motion of solid particles in turbulent channels is necessary to understand the sediment transport process and their effect on landform changes and impact on shipping routes. 

The emphasis of this work will be on generating and analyzing a data set for particle-turbulence interactions to understand the multiscale energy cascade mechanisms. The potential impact of this work will be in the fundamental understanding of two-phase flows and interfacial phenomena in complex environments where it is difficult to obtain detailed experimental data.  This will be a major step forward in large-scale computations of multi-physics turbulent flows. The intellectual merit includes training of two graduate students resulting in significant scholarly articles and educating them in high-performance parallel computing. The PI has received Office of Naval Research (ONR) grant (N00014-06-1-0697) for the above developments.

A-ices9.name: A-ices9
A-ices9.project_abstract: We are developing theory and algorithms to extend the time scale of simulations in molecular biophysics

TG-CTS160005.name: TG-CTS160005
TG-CTS160005.project_abstract:
This proposal requests XSEDE resource allocations for an NSF-funded research effort whose
objective is to perform a high-resolution, multiscale computational investigation of the role of
turbulence in driving droplet coalescence and growth in warm cumulus clouds. Cumulus clouds
exert significant influence on Earths climate by processing atmospheric aerosols, interacting
with electromagnetic radiation from the Sun and Earth, and redistributing Earths water and
energy through the hydrologic cycle. Existing climate models overestimate the empirically ob-
served times for precipitation initiation in warm clouds, the discrepancy arising primarily due to
an insufficient representation of microscale cloud processes. The current proposal, in conjunction
with an NSF grant (Award # 1436100), aims to address this problem by answering the central
outstanding question in cloud microphysics: What are the mechanisms leading to the formation
of fast-growing statistically fortunate drops that hasten the colloidal instability of the cloud,
resulting in precipitation? The primary hypothesis of this study is that turbulent shear and
acceleration play a crucial role in enabling droplets bridge the condensation-coalescence bot-
tleneck, thereby reducing the time for rain formation. To understand the role of turbulence,
it is essential to gain insights into the interactions between large-scale cloud processes such
as entrainment, mixing and intermittency, and microscale processes such as droplet clustering,
collisions and coalescence.

The principal obstacle to simulating turbulence-droplet interactions in a cumulus cloud is the
prohibitive computational expense associated with resolving the entire spectrum of turbulent
scales in a cloud, ranging from energy-containing scales that are O(10^2-10^3m) to dissipative
scales that are O(10^3m). To address this challenge, a novel multiscale computational approach
is being developed wherein the large-scale and microscale cloud processes are captured using
LES and DNS respectively, while the interactions between these processes are included through
a transfer of inertial-range kinetic energy from LES to DNS. Computational allocations are
therefore being requested to perform the first truly multiscale LES-DNS study of turbulence-
droplet interactions in a single, warm cumulus cloud. The multiscale approach consists of:
(1) Performing LES of turbulence from the energy-containing to the inertial scales in a single
cloud, such that turbulent intermittency is captured. New boundary conditions representative of
cloud-atmosphere interactions will be developed; and (2) Performing DNS of turbulence-droplet
interactions in the inertial to dissipative range of cloud turbulence, such that the microscale
processes driving droplet relative motion are resolved. The overlap between the LES- and DNS-
resolved scales in the inertial range will facilitate the inclusion of intermittency effects on droplet
dynamics using a novel LES to DNS energy transfer method.

The requested XSEDE resources will complement the PIs existing allocations on the NCSA
Blue Waters supercomputer (NSF Award # 1515248). The current XSEDE allocation request
aims to test and validate the hybrid LES-DNS approach through two principal tasks: (1) Per-
form LES of a single cloud and DNS of particle-laden isotropic turbulence at low to moderate
Reynolds numbers; and (2) Develop and test the LES to DNS energy transfer method, as well
as the boundary conditions for cloud LES. The validated methodolgies will be used to per-
form production-quality cloud simulations at realistic high Reynolds numbers on Blue Waters.
The proposed simulations are central to Mr. Rohit Dhariwals Ph.D research, and a favorable
consideration of this request is crucial to enable him complete his thesis.

TG-ATM130003.name: TG-ATM130003
TG-ATM130003.project_abstract: In response to the emerging research needs identified by National Research Council and Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, with support from NSF, we are developing an Integrated Technology-Driven Earth System Model (ITDEaSM) to link technology options, energy use, and policy choices and resultant emissions with Earth system processes that govern climate change, air quality, water quality, and ecosystem.  ITDEaSM will be developed by coupling and adding capability to a suite of community models to address grand challenges in decadal regional climate predictions and fill in major gaps in existing climate, Earth system, and ecosystem modeling.  Multi-decadal simulations will be performed using ITDEaSM to estimate the long-term impacts of global climate changes on the global-through-urban earth system, including air quality, water quality/supply, forest, and ecosystem.  Our ultimate goal is to quantify such impacts, reduce associated uncertainties, and identify technology choices for co-benefits of climate/Earth system mitigation. During this 1-year allocation time period, our work will focus on model improvement, testing, and initial applications, which will be conducted by 4 post-Ds and 8 graduate students in our project team.  A complex Earth system model like ITDEaSM requires significant high performance computing resources.  To achieve our goals, we request 5,000,000 SUs for computation (4,000,000 SUs on Kraken and 1,000,000 SUs on Ranger) and 50,000 SUs for Nautilus.
TG-ATM130003.pi_institution: North Carolina State University at Raleigh

TG-MCB150013.name: TG-MCB150013
TG-MCB150013.field_of_science: Biochemistry and Molecular Structure and Function
TG-MCB150013.project_abstract: To determine the 3-dimensional structures of a protein merely from its 1-dimensional sequence has been a major interest in the modern computational biology. Today, multiple approaches can be used to generate low-resolution models with 3~5 root-mean-square deviation (RMSD) from the native structure, while high-accuracy refinement is required to generate a high-resolution model (with 1~2 RMSD) from the low-resolution models. In the proposed project, we are going to combine parallel continuous simulated tempering (PCST) method, an enhanced sampling method we have developed recently, with the structured-based model (SBM) to further increase the sampling efficiency of rare events around important conformations in molecular simulation. The combined method will be applied in the refinement of 24 protein targets selected from the refinement category of the 10th Critical Assessment of Structure Prediction (CASP) experiments held in 2012. All-atom molecular simulations in explicit solvent will be performed to generate candidate models. Our method has already been coded into the latest GROMACS package and the preliminary testing shows some encouraging results.

TG-DMR080015N.name: TG-DMR080015N
TG-DMR080015N.project_abstract:
The key constituent of a photovoltaic cell is a material which is both optically transparent 
and electrically conductive. Attractive from fundamental and technological points of view, 
such a unique combination is attained in oxides of post-transition metals via intentional 
doping. Advances in theoretical understanding of the underlying physical phenomena 
in currently known transparent conducting oxides (TCO) stimulate further research aimed 
at designing novel application-specific materials which are more efficient, less expensive 
and environmentally friendly. 

This project will focus on the first-principles investigations of the structural, electronic 
and optical properties of complex multi-component oxides with layered structure, 
R2O3(MO)m where R = trivalent ion, M = divalent ion, and $m$=integer, 
to identify candidates for novel TCO hosts, to predict the most efficient carrier 
generation mechanism(s) in order to combine optical transparency with electrical conductivity 
in these materials and to determine the application range of each material. The proposed 
systems examplify the structural and combinatorial peculiarities of complex multicomponent 
oxides and offer a unique possibility to incorporate the main group metal oxides such as 
CaO, Al2O3 and SiO2, i.e., beyond the traditional In2O3, ZnO and SnO2, 
into novel TCO's with controllable optical and transport properties. This research work 
is pending a support from National Science Foundation. 

The research in this project builds on in-depth understanding of the underlying phenomena 
and previous successful work of the PI in the TCO area which includes not only detailed 
explanation of existing experiments, but also predictions of new materials and theory-guided 
measurements. The unique predictive power of the ab-initio band structure approach in this 
project will provide fundamental understanding of the underlying physical phenomena, 
the system behavior as well as novel and hidden functionalities in the proposed materials. 
Several state-of-the-art ab-initio density functional approaches will be employed 
for the electronic band structure investigations, including (i) highly precise all-electron 
full-potential linearized augmented plane wave (FLAPW) method; (2) linearized muffin-tin 
orbital method in the atomic sphere approximation (LMTO-ASA); and (3) DMol3 method. 
Previous extensive experience of the PI in the utilization of these methods will allow 
her to tackle each specific problem by choosing the most suitable technique or combining 
the advantages of several methods. Both the FLAPW and Dmol3 codes have been successfully 
parallelized.

To accomplish the proposed research, we are applying for a grant of 200,000 SUs on 
the TeraGrid cluster.
TG-DMR080015N.pi_institution: Missouri University of Science and Technology

TG-MCB080116N.name: TG-MCB080116N
TG-MCB080116N.project_abstract:
This project will focus on the energetics of the sequence of
  electronic transitions in bacteria resulting in the separation of
  charge across the membrane caused by the absorption of a photon of
  visible light. We will run classical MD trajectories of the
  bacterial reaction center in order to extract two types of
  information: dynamics of the fluctuations of the donor-acceptor
  energy gap for the electronic hops and the equilibrium distributions
  of energy gaps. The latter will provide us with the free energy
  surfaces of electronic hopping transitions directly used in the
  calculation of the reaction rates.  The main question we address in
  this study is the details of the mechanism by which natural systems
  eliminate wasteful recombination rates allowing quantum efficiency
  exceeding 99&. This information will be used to formulate practical
  suggestions for photosynthetic conversion of light energy applicable
  to artificial photosynthesis.

TG-DMR150017.name: TG-DMR150017
TG-DMR150017.project_abstract:
Semiconductor heterostructures are one of the fundamental platforms for many important device
applications such as solar cells, diodes, bipolar transistors, and lasers. Analogous to traditional
heterostructures, novel two-dimensional (2D) layered heterostructures can be designed and built by
assembling individual single layers of distinct materials into functional multilayer structures. Our
rst-principles simulations aim to study physical and chemical properties and interfacial phenomena
in this new class of van der Waals (vdW) heterostructures for applications in photovoltaics, 
exible
electronics, and energy storage devices. In particular, vdW heterostructures based on the assembly
of organic crystals (e.g. C60, pentacene, rubrene) and 2D crystals (e.g. graphene) have been
recently attracting intense research eorts as a promising opportunity for exploring novel physical
phenomena induced by quantum coherent electronic states in these low dimensional systems. In
addition to using pre-existing codes, we propose to develop codes for rst-principles simulations
which provide a balance between accuracy and eciency in the context of the current hardware
architecture. To advance our current research program we request an allocation of 436K SUs in a
project that will be performed in collaboration with the experimental group led by Prof. Qing Hua
Wang of Arizona State University (Co-PI in this proposal). Initial performance and scaling tests at
TACC supermachine Stampede have established the value of XSEDE resources for this work, and
allowed us to predict our computational requirements for the next phase of our research, which far
exceed the capacity available from local resources utilized in our startup allocation.
The work is funded by startup grants from Arizona State University and Queen's University
Research.

TG-OCE130015.name: TG-OCE130015
TG-OCE130015.project_abstract: The coastal ocean, including the continental shelf and the estuaries, is where society meets the sea.  Our circulation modeling activities within the College of Marine Science, University of South Florida are intended to advance our understandings on this important region and provide applications of societal relevance.  Two such projects require high performance computing capabilities beyond our present resources and hence our proposal to the Extreme Science and Engineering Discovery Environment (XSEDE).  The two projects are: 1) a high resolution model that downscales from the deep ocean, across the continental shelf and into the estuaries with present application domain extending from west of the Mississippi River Delta to south of the Florida Keys, encompassing the continental shelf and estuarine regions of the northern Gulf of Mexico and west Florida and 2) a very high resolution model for Tampa Bay.  The modeling approach consists of nesting an unstructured grid coastal ocean model into a Gulf of Mexico structured model run by the Naval Research Laboratory.  The structured model provides the open boundary values and the unstructured model allows us to consider the coastal ocean responses to both the deep ocean forcing and the local forcing by winds and buoyancy fluxes.  The resolution from 1) above is generally sufficient for many applications.  Nevertheless when considering spatial scales associated with shipping channels and other important conveyances of mass it becomes useful to include even higher resolution as in 2) above.  Applications for 1) presently in consideration include how the coastal ocean is ventilated by the deep ocean, thereby changing nutrients and other state variables with impacts on shelf ecology, fish larvae recruitment, harmful algal blooms, tracking hazardous spills, impacts of fresh water diversion for municipal and agricultural use, search and rescue, and helping to expand the use of satellite altimetry to the coastal ocean.  Applications for 2) include diagnoses of the potential effects on Tampa Bay by channel deepening and widening to accommodate larger vessels, flushing studies of chronic sub-regions of the bay and fish larvae recruitment.  Necessary for achieving these goals is the computational resource of XSEDE.  We note that the societal applications for the regions 1) and 2) above are portable to other regions by virtue of the nesting procedures developed and the global coverage of the Naval Research Laboratory model to which we nest.

CCBB.name: CCBB
CCBB.project_abstract: The Center for Computational Biology and Bioinformatics will be hosting its first Summer School for Big Data in Biology (see http://ccbb.biosci.utexas.edu/summerschool.html) May 19-22, 2014. Some of our courses teach students how to use TACC for high performance computing, so we would like to get TACC accounts and an allocation set up for the registered students, and the folks who run the Summer Statistics Institute.

TG-EAR080022N.name: TG-EAR080022N
TG-EAR080022N.project_abstract: The Computational Infrastructure for Geodynamics (CIG), an NSF center, develops and maintains open-source geodynamics software in support of the NSF-supported Earth science community. The goal of CIGs efforts is to provide software that will help researchers and students address important unsolved problems in geophysics, including problems in mantle dynamics, crustal and lithospheric dynamics on both million-year and earthquake time-scales, and seismic wave propagation. CIG engaged in these activities under an MRAC and requested to upgrade to an LRAC in January 2008, as the positive response from the community has been consuming its present TeraGrid allocation at a substantially higher rate than anticipated. This proposal justification will answer questions and address issues raised by the LRAC Review Board. In the previously submitted LRAC application, CIG proposed to continue to promote four geodynamics codes through operation and further development of its science gateway and by pre-installing more codes in TeraGrids Community Software Area. The Seismology Science Gateway, already deployed, features SPECFEM3D_GLOBE, a spectral-element code that simulates global and regional (continental-scale) seismic wave propagation; SPECFEM3D, which simulates southern California seismic wave propagation, is a planned future addition. Three CIG finite-element codes (CitcomS, Gale, and PyLith) are all state-of-the art and scale well on a variety of TeraGrid platforms. Using a powerful, yet simplified interface that will run and benchmark these applications via a web browser, we hope to increase the ability of the Earth Sciences community to access TeraGrid resources. A benchmarking tool, the CIG Model Analyzer (Cigma), will also be offered as a web service. An allocation is requested for four activities: (1) operation and continued development of the science gateway, (2) benchmarking, (3) workshops and training sessions, and (4) nurturing new users on the TeraGrid using CIG software.

TG-MCB140147.name: TG-MCB140147
TG-MCB140147.project_abstract:
We have developed and continue to support the Galaxy genomic analysis system. Our main public Galaxy analysis website currently supports more than 50,000 genomics researchers performing hundreds of thousands of analysis jobs every month. Many academic and commercial institutions around the world operate private Galaxy instances.

Galaxy enables biomedical researchers to perform complex compute-intensive analyses with nothing to install and configure. It also allows tool developers to deploy their analysis applications without the need to design interfaces and maintain compute infrastructure. Both of these are profoundly felt. Despite the fact we do not put any requirements on citing our work, over 500 papers published in 2013 alone have utilized Galaxy as the analysis platform.

As a direct consequence of our initial success we have reached a point where we can no longer sustain the exponential growth of analysis load and associated biological data storage on our public servers. In order to extend our capacity we are requesting XSEDE Gateway allocation aimed at establishing a national computational biology gateway.

TG-CCR140039.name: TG-CCR140039
TG-CCR140039.pi_institution: University of Puerto Rico at Mayagüez

WhiteleyLabNGS.name: WhiteleyLabNGS
WhiteleyLabNGS.project_abstract: Recent advances in high-throughput (or next-generation) sequencing-based technologies have greatly advanced the scope of biological studies. Microorganisms such as bacteria, with their rapid growth and relatively small genome sizes, represent an optimal opportunity to exploit these advances. I and my labmates in the Whiteley lab are interested in applying a number of high-throughput sequencing-based methods to the study of microbiology, including RNA-Seq, TnSeq and whole genome sequencing. TACC will accelerate the pace of post-sequencing data parsing and analysis by many orders of magnitude. Many of the processes involved are serial in nature, but TACC will allow us to process many samples in parallel at high speed and with exceptional software support.
WhiteleyLabNGS.pi_institution: Section of Molecular Genetics and Microbiology

TG-MCA09X003.name: TG-MCA09X003
TG-MCA09X003.project_abstract:
Having constructed a scalable code capable of evolving astrophysically
relevant systems including magnetized neutron stars and black holes,
we request time to continue our runs towards further understanding of
these strong field phenomena. In particular, our code uses MPI and
AMR to make efficient use of large scale computational resources
as well as advanced computational techniques such as higher order
finite differencing, high resolution shock capturing for
magnetohydrodynamics, and black hole excision  in order to evolve
such systems while extracting useful information about the produced
gravitational wave signatures. Further efforts are underway to 
increase the scalability as well as add the ability to track
radiation transport.

AGTracts.name: AGTracts
AGTracts.project_abstract: Homopolymeric stretches of deoxyadenosine or deoxyguanosine nucleotides, called A/G-tracts, are ubiquitous DNA elements in regulatory regions of many organisms. The molecular structure of these DNA tracts is unusual and distinct from that of canonical B-DNA, and we postulate that the biological importance of A/G-tracts resides in part in their distinct structural properties. Indeed, our current bioinformatics analyses indicate that both mutation frequencies and mutation spectra in the genome of human individuals (from the 1000Genomes Project) vary depending on the length of the tracts, the relative position of the A.T and G.C base pairs within the tracts themselves and the nature of nearest flanking base-pairs. In this project, we aim to combine bioinformatics and molecular dynamics methods to study the structural and dynamic properties of A/G-tracts, and in particular the role of first shell of hydration near the DNA molecules. The spine of hydration in A-tracts exist in crystal structures, and has been shown to play an important role in allowing DNA to distort to accommodate the highly bent structure needed to form nucleosomes. Thus, some of our current bioinformatics data may be interpreted in terms of sequence-dependent flexibility and solvation behavior in A-tracts. We plan to conduct molecular dynamics simulations of G-tracts of different lengths and to study the effect of the flanking base pair on both the 5’ and 3’ sides, so as to connect the genomic information with the unusual properties of A/G-tracts. This will be a collaborative project between the Vasquez group at Dell Pediatric Research Institute (DPRI) and Dr. Xiao Zhu at Texas Advanced Computing Center (TACC).  The molecular dynamics simulations will be performed with Amber99 force field with bsc0 modification using molecular modeling programs of NAMD or CHARMM. To this end, we kindly request computational resources on both Lonestar (50K SUs) and Stampede (100K SUs).

TG-PHY140019.name: TG-PHY140019
TG-PHY140019.project_abstract:
The NSF's LIGO gravitational wave detectors are among a number of new
facilities all over the world which are designed to directly detect and
measure gravitational waves. These waves will come from a variety of
astrophysical sources and will open a new window to the universe. One of the
most promising sources for these detectors are the inspirals and mergers of
neutron star binaries. As the two objects get close, fully non-linear
numerical simulations of the Einstein equations are required to make 
predictions about the final part of the inspiral and subsequent merger. We
propose to use the moving puncture method together with high a resolution
shock capturing scheme (as implemented in the BAM code) to explore more
physically realistic situations. In particular, we plan to address several 
key physics issues such as: (i) How important is neutron star spin in the
evolutions of neutron star binaries? (ii) Can we find information about the
equation of state of neutron star matter even if the stars are allowed to 
have spin? To answer these questions we plan to perform the first long-term,
detailed 3+1 simulations of binary neutron stars with spin, to explore a
relevant fraction of the parameter space and to use this data to support the
development of gravitational wave templates for gravitational wave
astronomy. For our simulations we request 8776960 SU, preferably on
Stampede.

Amorphous-Ceramics.name: Amorphous-Ceramics
Amorphous-Ceramics.project_abstract:
We study phase segregations (clustering, nucleation) in glasses (borates, silicates) and amorphous ceramics (SiBCN, SiCO, ZrSiBCN). Models of disordered and segregated structures are generated via a network algorithm or by standard melt-quench method involving ab-initio molecular dynamic simulations. Density functional theory methods are used to compute properties and to analyze signatures of clustering and segregation of precipitates embedded in the surrounding amorphous matrix.

One topic are polymer-derived ceramics (SiNO, SiCO) for which we study several hundred disordered structures and, in addition, thousands of well-ordered crystalline models. properties computed include enthalpy differences, interfacial energies between carbon segregations and glass matrix, NMR spectra and vibrational signatures, and the process of Li insertion and intercalation.

Another topic are metal oxide glasses (silicates and borates), for which we elucidate differences between homogeneous mixtures and segregated models. Currently, we focus on vibrational properties and optical response functions.

TG-AST140063.name: TG-AST140063
TG-AST140063.project_abstract: The scope of this proposal is to perform high-resolution cosmological hydrodynamic simulations in order to understand the physical processes which shape galaxies within a representative portion of the Universe. Our project is a follow-up of the recently completed Illustris Simulation Suite. We plan to perform and analyze five simulations for galaxy formation, four of which of the same volume of Illustris and one with half its box size, with fewer resolution elements than Illustris, but with different variations of the underlying adopted physics model and feedback schemes. To do so we propose to run the code AREPO on 4096 cores/MPI-tasks of the TACC/Stampede machine, for which we request 15.5 million CPU hours. The proposed simulations are crucial for understanding the impact of variations in the underlying physics model on the galaxy population, for addressing the limitations of our previous works, and for making better connections with currently available and upcoming observations.

TG-DMR150099.name: TG-DMR150099
TG-DMR150099.project_abstract:
This is a new proposal for an XSEDE research allocation, which will support the research on
computational modeling of advanced materials in the group of Prof. Anderson Janotti in the
Department of Materials Science and Engineering at the University of Delaware (UD). The
computational resources will be used to perform electronic structure calculations for a series
of functional materials which are the focus of research grants funded by the Department
of Energy, University of Delaware, and the National Science Foundation (a research
proposal is currently being prepared for submission to the Division of Materials Research).

First-principles calculations, based on the density functional theory, constitute a
powerful tool to investigate the structural, electronic, optical, and magnetic properties of
materials. These calculations have greatly contributed to fundamental understanding of
the electronic structure of materials and the response to mechanical, electric, magnetic, and
optical excitations. The materials that are the focus of this project are complex oxides, Heusler
and half-Heusler compounds, and layered chalcogenide materials. The goal is to understand
the fundamental relationship between chemical composition, structure, electronic,
and transport properties of these materials, in close connection to current experimental
work at UD and elsewhere.

These studies employ advanced algorithms that necessarily demand the use of highperformance
parallel computation. Prof. Janotti has demonstrated extensive experience in
the area of computational materials science, with emphasis on first-principles calculations,
and has established a strong record in the areas of doping and defects in oxide and nitride
semiconductors, semiconductor surfaces and interfaces, hydrogen impurities in materials,
and complex-oxide heterostructures.

TG-OCE150003.name: TG-OCE150003
TG-OCE150003.project_abstract:
High performance computing resources are requested in support of the West Coast component of the Coastal Ocean Modeling Testbed project, currently funded by NOAA via the Southeastern University Research Association (SURA). As part of this project, Oregon State University is testing new methodologies for variational data assimilation in a high resolution coastal ocean forecast model along Oregon and Washington coasts. New methodologies for data assimilation will be transitioned to the real-time coastal ocean forecast system that currently provides everyday updates of 3 day forecasts of ocean conditions, in support of environmental hazard response, search and rescue, fisheries etc. (http://ingria.coas.oregonstate.edu/rtdav/). In addition, as part of the same project, OSU has been involved in development of a similar forecast system for the entire West Coast. Currently research with the OR-WA is focused on development of a hybrid variational-ensemble assimilation system, in which the model error covariance is computed using an ensemble of model forecasts. Given this covariance, the variational method requires repeated application of the tangent linear and adjoint model components. In order to demonstrate that the new approach yields improvement in ocean state estimates, hindcast simulations are needed for a model period of at least several months. The system has been developed and initially tested using our local resources, namely a cluster of two 64 CPU shared memory nodes, connected by an InfiniBand switch (this system was purchased and assembled about 1 year ago). The ensemble in this hindcast consists of 60 members and model results for each of these members are calculated using a parallel version of the Regional Ocean Modeling System (ROMS, www.myroms.org). Initial results (over a 40 day interval) suggest improvement in subsurface fields as result of assimilation of surface fields. For conclusive results, a longer run is needed. With our current resources, running the hindcast for a 6-month model period is expected to take 100 days, which is prohibitively long (esp. thinking that we will need to re-run the system repeatedly in sensitivity studies). Therefore we would like to investigate the possibility to run the hindcast on an XSEDE system. The startup allocation is requested to run the hindcast model for two six day periods plus a trial run.  This is with the purpose to

1) establish on which XSEDE clusters are suitable for the model
2) obtain the necessary SU estimates to write a XSEDE research proposal.

Shale-Fracture.name: Shale-Fracture
Shale-Fracture.project_abstract: We have developed a three-dimensional code using LAMMPS with custom extensions that simulates a coupled rock-fluid system for the simulation of hydrofracturing. In preliminary work with a two-dimensional version of the code we have recovered analytical solutions in simple cases. Now we hope to explore more realistic cases by proceeding to three dimensions.

TG-CTS110025.name: TG-CTS110025
TG-CTS110025.project_abstract: We request computing time and storage space on TeraGrid resources, preferably the newly deployed Lonestar  or similar cluster systems, to produce a suite of simulations of the flow physics of insect flight which will support the research outlined in an NSF CAREER award to the PI, ``CAREER: Flapping in the Wind -- Passive Mechanisms in Insect Wings for Flight Stabilization'' (Grant No. CBET-0954381).  In the proposed simulations, we will apply computational fluid dynamics (CFD) to model the three-dimensional aerodynamics and aeroelasticity of the deformable insect wing and to evaluate the comprehensive role of the structural flexibility in the wing's aerodynamic performance.  The numerical method couples an immersed-boundary method for the flow solver and a finite-element method for the structural solver.  The specific studies include the following three model configurations: (1) a flapping/pitching plate in hovering flight, (2) a pitching plate in a uniform freestream, and (3) a dragonfly wing model with the simplified vein structure.  The code has been developed and tested on the previous Lonestar and other clusters.  Our request for 1.0M SUs will enable a fundamental investigation of the potential benefit brought by the wing flexibility for flapping-wing propelled biomimetic micro air vehicles.

TG-PHY100033.name: TG-PHY100033
TG-PHY100033.project_abstract:
One century after Einstein's theory of general relativity has revealed space and time as dynamical entities, research in gravitation is preparing for a dramatically rising tide of observational data, adding gravitational waves to the messenger ensemble of astrophysics.  The first detection of gravitational waves will push open a new window on the universe, comparable to the revolutions brought about by the development of radio, infrared, and high-energy (UV/X/$\gamma$-ray) astronomy. Prime candidates for first detection are catastrophic events involving compact relativistic objects and their strongly nonlinear gravitational fields, in particular the coalescence of compact binaries and stellar collapse.

The challenge to meet the tremendous sensitivity requirements of gravitational wave detectors is paralleled by a computational modeling challenge: The detection, identification, and accurate determination of the physical parameters of sources relies on the detailed theoretical understanding of the source physics, and, in many cases, on the availability of waveform template banks, which are used to filter the detector signals. 

For coalescing compact binaries, good analytical approximations for the gravitational waveforms are provided by post-Newtonian expansion techniques as long as the orbits are wide. For the last obits and merger, where the fields are particularly strong, and where one has the best chances of discovering entirely new physics, the full Einstein equations have to be solved numerically on supercomputers. The latter is true also and in particular for stellar collapse to a protoneutron star and the subsequent evolution to a core-collapse supernova or to stellar-mass black hole formation and a potential late-time gamma-ray burst. In this case, gravitational wave data can be complemented by information carried by neutrinos and electromagnetic waves.

Our group of researchers has been involved at the heart of the recent progress in numerical relativity that is now allowing for robust simulations of compact binary coalescence, merger, and post-merger evolution as well as simulations of stellar collapse and core-collapse supernova evolution in full general relativity.
 
Here we propose to carry out computational relativistic astrophysics modeling of stellar collapse and binary black hole coalescence, following novel research directions, employing new technical approaches while fundamentally relying on the community infrastructure Cactus that we helped create.

Over the last few years, we have invested much work into black hole binary simulations and pioneered many of the techniques that render possible large scale parameter studies of these systems, and to construct from such simulations analytical template banks that describe the inspiral, merger and ringdown of black hole binaries. The binary black hole part of this project will make it possible to combine all these techniques and leap-frog black hole parameter studies in time for establishing data analysis strategies for the advanced generation of GW detectors that is expected to come online in 2014.

We have equally been at the forefront in the modeling of the general relativistic collapse of massive stars to neutron stars and in simulations of core-collapse supernovae and the accretion-induced collapse of massive white dwarfs. In addition, we have recently developed and published much improved treatments and implementations for highly-relevant neutrino processes and the microphysical finite-temperature nuclear equation of state. The 3D stellar collapse projects that we propose here focus on the formation of black holes in failing core-collapse supernovae and on comparing 2D (axisymmetric) and 3D core-collapse supernova dynamics. The former is aimed at understanding the formation of gamma-ray burst central engines while the latter will help ascertain the influence of multi-D phenomena on the core-collapse supernova explosion mechanism. In addition, these simulations will yield new and improved estimates of the gravitational wave signature of stellar collapse, core-collapse supernovae, and black hole formation.

TG-AST130021.name: TG-AST130021
